39def _process_plot_format(fmt): 

40 """ 

41 Process a MATLAB style color/line style format string. Return a 

42 (*linestyle*, *color*) tuple as a result of the processing. Default 

43 values are ('-', 'b'). Example format strings include: 

44 

45 * 'ko': black circles 

46 * '.b': blue dots 

47 * 'r--': red dashed lines 

48 * 'C2--': the third color in the color cycle, dashed lines 

49 

50 .. seealso:: 

51 

52 :func:`~matplotlib.Line2D.lineStyles` and 

53 :attr:`~matplotlib.colors.cnames` 

54 for all possible styles and color format string. 

55 """ 

56 

57 linestyle = None 

58 marker = None 

59 color = None 

60 

61 # Is fmt just a colorspec? 

62 try: 

63 color = mcolors.to_rgba(fmt) 

64 

65 # We need to differentiate grayscale '1.0' from tri_down marker '1' 

66 try: 

67 fmtint = str(int(fmt)) 

68 except ValueError: 

69 return linestyle, marker, color # Yes 

70 else: 

71 if fmt != fmtint: 

72 # user definitely doesn't want tri_down marker 

73 return linestyle, marker, color # Yes 

74 else: 

75 # ignore converted color 

76 color = None 

77 except ValueError: 

78 pass # No, not just a color. 

79 

80 # handle the multi char special cases and strip them from the 

81 # string 

82 if fmt.find('--') >= 0: 

83 linestyle = '--' 

84 fmt = fmt.replace('--', '') 

85 if fmt.find('-.') >= 0: 

86 linestyle = '-.' 

87 fmt = fmt.replace('-.', '') 

88 if fmt.find(' ') >= 0: 

89 linestyle = 'None' 

90 fmt = fmt.replace(' ', '') 

91 

92 chars = [c for c in fmt] 

93 

94 i = 0 

95 while i < len(chars): 

96 c = chars[i] 

97 if c in mlines.lineStyles: 

98 if linestyle is not None: 

99 raise ValueError( 

100 'Illegal format string "%s"; two linestyle symbols' % fmt) 

101 linestyle = c 

102 elif c in mlines.lineMarkers: 

103 if marker is not None: 

104 raise ValueError( 

105 'Illegal format string "%s"; two marker symbols' % fmt) 

106 marker = c 

107 elif c in mcolors.get_named_colors_mapping(): 

108 if color is not None: 

109 raise ValueError( 

110 'Illegal format string "%s"; two color symbols' % fmt) 

111 color = c 

112 elif c == 'C' and i < len(chars) - 1: 

113 color_cycle_number = int(chars[i + 1]) 

114 color = mcolors.to_rgba("C{}".format(color_cycle_number)) 

115 i += 1 

116 else: 

117 raise ValueError( 

118 'Unrecognized character %c in format string' % c) 

119 i += 1 

120 

121 if linestyle is None and marker is None: 

122 linestyle = rcParams['lines.linestyle'] 

123 if linestyle is None: 

124 linestyle = 'None' 

125 if marker is None: 

126 marker = 'None' 

127 

128 return linestyle, marker, color

131class _process_plot_var_args(object): 

132 """ 

133 Process variable length arguments to the plot command, so that 

134 plot commands like the following are supported:: 

135 

136 plot(t, s) 

137 plot(t1, s1, t2, s2) 

138 plot(t1, s1, 'ko', t2, s2) 

139 plot(t1, s1, 'ko', t2, s2, 'r--', t3, e3) 

140 

141 an arbitrary number of *x*, *y*, *fmt* are allowed 

142 """ 

143 def __init__(self, axes, command='plot'): 

144 self.axes = axes 

145 self.command = command 

146 self.set_prop_cycle() 

147 

148 def __getstate__(self): 

149 # note: it is not possible to pickle a generator (and thus a cycler). 

150 return {'axes': self.axes, 'command': self.command} 

151 

152 def __setstate__(self, state): 

153 self.__dict__ = state.copy() 

154 self.set_prop_cycle() 

155 

156 def set_prop_cycle(self, *args, **kwargs): 

157 # Can't do `args == (None,)` as that crashes cycler. 

158 if not (args or kwargs) or (len(args) == 1 and args[0] is None): 

159 prop_cycler = rcParams['axes.prop_cycle'] 

160 else: 

161 prop_cycler = cycler(*args, **kwargs) 

162 

163 self.prop_cycler = itertools.cycle(prop_cycler) 

164 # This should make a copy 

165 self._prop_keys = prop_cycler.keys 

166 

167 def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): 

168 if self.axes.xaxis is not None and self.axes.yaxis is not None: 

169 xunits = kwargs.pop('xunits', self.axes.xaxis.units) 

170 

171 if self.axes.name == 'polar': 

172 xunits = kwargs.pop('thetaunits', xunits) 

173 

174 yunits = kwargs.pop('yunits', self.axes.yaxis.units) 

175 

176 if self.axes.name == 'polar': 

177 yunits = kwargs.pop('runits', yunits) 

178 

179 if xunits != self.axes.xaxis.units: 

180 self.axes.xaxis.set_units(xunits) 

181 

182 if yunits != self.axes.yaxis.units: 

183 self.axes.yaxis.set_units(yunits) 

184 

185 ret = self._grab_next_args(*args, **kwargs) 

186 return ret 

187 

188 def get_next_color(self): 

189 """Return the next color in the cycle.""" 

190 if 'color' not in self._prop_keys: 

191 return 'k' 

192 return next(self.prop_cycler)['color'] 

193 

194 def set_lineprops(self, line, **kwargs): 

195 assert self.command == 'plot', 'set_lineprops only works with "plot"' 

196 line.set(**kwargs) 

197 

198 def set_patchprops(self, fill_poly, **kwargs): 

199 assert self.command == 'fill', 'set_patchprops only works with "fill"' 

200 fill_poly.set(**kwargs) 

201 

202 def _xy_from_xy(self, x, y): 

203 if self.axes.xaxis is not None and self.axes.yaxis is not None: 

204 bx = self.axes.xaxis.update_units(x) 

205 by = self.axes.yaxis.update_units(y) 

206 

207 if self.command != 'plot': 

208 # the Line2D class can handle unitized data, with 

209 # support for post hoc unit changes etc. Other mpl 

210 # artists, e.g., Polygon which _process_plot_var_args 

211 # also serves on calls to fill, cannot. So this is a 

212 # hack to say: if you are not "plot", which is 

213 # creating Line2D, then convert the data now to 

214 # floats. If you are plot, pass the raw data through 

215 # to Line2D which will handle the conversion. So 

216 # polygons will not support post hoc conversions of 

217 # the unit type since they are not storing the orig 

218 # data. Hopefully we can rationalize this at a later 

219 # date - JDH 

220 if bx: 

221 x = self.axes.convert_xunits(x) 

222 if by: 

223 y = self.axes.convert_yunits(y) 

224 

225 # like asanyarray, but converts scalar to array, and doesn't change 

226 # existing compatible sequences 

227 x = _check_1d(x) 

228 y = _check_1d(y) 

229 if x.shape[0] != y.shape[0]: 

230 raise ValueError("x and y must have same first dimension, but " 

231 "have shapes {} and {}".format(x.shape, y.shape)) 

232 if x.ndim > 2 or y.ndim > 2: 

233 raise ValueError("x and y can be no greater than 2-D, but have " 

234 "shapes {} and {}".format(x.shape, y.shape)) 

235 

236 if x.ndim == 1: 

237 x = x[:, np.newaxis] 

238 if y.ndim == 1: 

239 y = y[:, np.newaxis] 

240 return x, y 

241 

242 def _getdefaults(self, ignore, *kwargs): 

243 """ 

244 Only advance the cycler if the cycler has information that 

245 is not specified in any of the supplied tuple of dicts. 

246 Ignore any keys specified in the `ignore` set. 

247 

248 Returns a copy of defaults dictionary if there are any 

249 keys that are not found in any of the supplied dictionaries. 

250 If the supplied dictionaries have non-None values for 

251 everything the property cycler has, then just return 

252 an empty dictionary. Ignored keys are excluded from the 

253 returned dictionary. 

254 

255 """ 

256 prop_keys = self._prop_keys 

257 if ignore is None: 

258 ignore = set() 

259 prop_keys = prop_keys - ignore 

260 

261 if any(all(kw.get(k, None) is None for kw in kwargs) 

262 for k in prop_keys): 

263 # Need to copy this dictionary or else the next time around 

264 # in the cycle, the dictionary could be missing entries. 

265 default_dict = next(self.prop_cycler).copy() 

266 for p in ignore: 

267 default_dict.pop(p, None) 

268 else: 

269 default_dict = {} 

270 return default_dict 

271 

272 def _setdefaults(self, defaults, *kwargs): 

273 """ 

274 Given a defaults dictionary, and any other dictionaries, 

275 update those other dictionaries with information in defaults if 

276 none of the other dictionaries contains that information. 

277 

278 """ 

279 for k in defaults: 

280 if all(kw.get(k, None) is None for kw in kwargs): 

281 for kw in kwargs: 

282 kw[k] = defaults[k] 

283 

284 def _makeline(self, x, y, kw, kwargs): 

285 kw = {**kw, **kwargs} # Don't modify the original kw. 

286 default_dict = self._getdefaults(None, kw) 

287 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kw) 

288 seg = mlines.Line2D(x, y, **kw) 

289 return seg 

290 

291 def _makefill(self, x, y, kw, kwargs): 

292 kw = kw.copy() # Don't modify the original kw. 

293 kwargs = kwargs.copy() 

294 

295 # Ignore 'marker'-related properties as they aren't Polygon 

296 # properties, but they are Line2D properties, and so they are 

297 # likely to appear in the default cycler construction. 

298 # This is done here to the defaults dictionary as opposed to the 

299 # other two dictionaries because we do want to capture when a 

300 # *user* explicitly specifies a marker which should be an error. 

301 # We also want to prevent advancing the cycler if there are no 

302 # defaults needed after ignoring the given properties. 

303 ignores = {'marker', 'markersize', 'markeredgecolor', 

304 'markerfacecolor', 'markeredgewidth'} 

305 # Also ignore anything provided by *kwargs*. 

306 for k, v in kwargs.items(): 

307 if v is not None: 

308 ignores.add(k) 

309 

310 # Only using the first dictionary to use as basis 

311 # for getting defaults for back-compat reasons. 

312 # Doing it with both seems to mess things up in 

313 # various places (probably due to logic bugs elsewhere). 

314 default_dict = self._getdefaults(ignores, kw) 

315 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kw) 

316 

317 # Looks like we don't want "color" to be interpreted to 

318 # mean both facecolor and edgecolor for some reason. 

319 # So the "kw" dictionary is thrown out, and only its 

320 # 'color' value is kept and translated as a 'facecolor'. 

321 # This design should probably be revisited as it increases 

322 # complexity. 

323 facecolor = kw.get('color', None) 

324 

325 # Throw out 'color' as it is now handled as a facecolor 

326 default_dict.pop('color', None) 

327 

328 # To get other properties set from the cycler 

329 # modify the kwargs dictionary. 

330 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kwargs) 

331 

332 seg = mpatches.Polygon(np.column_stack((x, y)), 

333 facecolor=facecolor, 

334 fill=kwargs.get('fill', True), 

335 closed=kw['closed']) 

336 self.set_patchprops(seg, **kwargs) 

337 return seg 

338 

339 def _plot_args(self, tup, kwargs): 

340 ret = [] 

341 if len(tup) > 1 and isinstance(tup[-1], str): 

342 linestyle, marker, color = _process_plot_format(tup[-1]) 

343 tup = tup[:-1] 

344 elif len(tup) == 3: 

345 raise ValueError('third arg must be a format string') 

346 else: 

347 linestyle, marker, color = None, None, None 

348 

349 # Don't allow any None value; These will be up-converted 

350 # to one element array of None which causes problems 

351 # downstream. 

352 if any(v is None for v in tup): 

353 raise ValueError("x, y, and format string must not be None") 

354 

355 kw = {} 

356 for k, v in zip(('linestyle', 'marker', 'color'), 

357 (linestyle, marker, color)): 

358 if v is not None: 

359 kw[k] = v 

360 

361 if 'label' not in kwargs or kwargs['label'] is None: 

362 kwargs['label'] = get_label(tup[-1], None) 

363 

364 if len(tup) == 2: 

365 x = _check_1d(tup[0]) 

366 y = _check_1d(tup[-1]) 

367 else: 

368 x, y = index_of(tup[-1]) 

369 

370 x, y = self._xy_from_xy(x, y) 

371 

372 if self.command == 'plot': 

373 func = self._makeline 

374 else: 

375 kw['closed'] = kwargs.get('closed', True) 

376 func = self._makefill 

377 

378 ncx, ncy = x.shape[1], y.shape[1] 

379 if ncx > 1 and ncy > 1 and ncx != ncy: 

380 cbook.warn_deprecated("2.2", "cycling among columns of inputs " 

381 "with non-matching shapes is deprecated.") 

382 for j in range(max(ncx, ncy)): 

383 seg = func(x[:, j % ncx], y[:, j % ncy], kw, kwargs) 

384 ret.append(seg) 

385 return ret 

386 

387 def _grab_next_args(self, *args, **kwargs): 

388 while args: 

389 this, args = args[:2], args[2:] 

390 if args and isinstance(args[0], str): 

391 this += args[0], 

392 args = args[1:] 

393 yield from self._plot_args(this, kwargs)

549 def __getstate__(self): 

550 # The renderer should be re-created by the figure, and then cached at 

551 # that point. 

552 state = super().__getstate__() 

553 for key in ['_cachedRenderer', '_layoutbox', '_poslayoutbox']: 

554 state[key] = None 

555 # Prune the sharing & twinning info to only contain the current group. 

556 for grouper_name in [ 

557 '_shared_x_axes', '_shared_y_axes', '_twinned_axes']: 

558 grouper = getattr(self, grouper_name) 

559 state[grouper_name] = (grouper.get_siblings(self) 

560 if self in grouper else None) 

561 return state 

562 

563 def __setstate__(self, state): 

564 # Merge the grouping info back into the global groupers. 

565 for grouper_name in [ 

566 '_shared_x_axes', '_shared_y_axes', '_twinned_axes']: 

567 siblings = state.pop(grouper_name) 

568 if siblings: 

569 getattr(self, grouper_name).join(*siblings) 

570 self.__dict__ = state 

571 self._stale = True 

572 

573 def get_window_extent(self, *args, **kwargs): 

574 """ 

575 get the axes bounding box in display space; *args* and 

576 *kwargs* are empty 

577 """ 

578 bbox = self.bbox 

579 x_pad = 0 

580 if self.axison and self.xaxis.get_visible(): 

581 x_pad = self.xaxis.get_tick_padding() 

582 y_pad = 0 

583 if self.axison and self.yaxis.get_visible(): 

584 y_pad = self.yaxis.get_tick_padding() 

585 return mtransforms.Bbox([[bbox.x0 - x_pad, bbox.y0 - y_pad], 

586 [bbox.x1 + x_pad, bbox.y1 + y_pad]])

606 martist.Artist.set_figure(self, fig) 

607

609 fig.transFigure) 

610 # these will be updated later as data is added 

611 self.dataLim = mtransforms.Bbox.null() 

612 self.viewLim = mtransforms.Bbox.unit() 

613 self.transScale = mtransforms.TransformWrapper(

618 def _set_lim_and_transforms(self): 

619 """ 

620 set the *_xaxis_transform*, *_yaxis_transform*, 

621 *transScale*, *transData*, *transLimits* and *transAxes* 

622 transformations. 

623 

624 .. note:: 

625 

626 This method is primarily used by rectilinear projections 

627 of the :class:`~matplotlib.axes.Axes` class, and is meant 

628 to be overridden by new kinds of projection axes that need 

629 different transformations and limits. (See 

630 :class:`~matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes` for an 

631 example. 

632 

633 """ 

634 self.transAxes = mtransforms.BboxTransformTo(self.bbox) 

635 

636 # Transforms the x and y axis separately by a scale factor. 

637 # It is assumed that this part will have non-linear components 

638 # (e.g., for a log scale). 

639 self.transScale = mtransforms.TransformWrapper( 

640 mtransforms.IdentityTransform()) 

641 

642 # An affine transformation on the data, generally to limit the 

643 # range of the axes 

644 self.transLimits = mtransforms.BboxTransformFrom( 

645 mtransforms.TransformedBbox(self.viewLim, self.transScale)) 

646 

647 # The parentheses are important for efficiency here -- they 

648 # group the last two (which are usually affines) separately 

649 # from the first (which, with log-scaling can be non-affine). 

650 self.transData = self.transScale + (self.transLimits + self.transAxes) 

651 

652 self._xaxis_transform = mtransforms.blended_transform_factory( 

653 self.transData, self.transAxes) 

654 self._yaxis_transform = mtransforms.blended_transform_factory( 

655 self.transAxes, self.transData) 

656 

657 def get_xaxis_transform(self, which='grid'): 

658 """ 

659 Get the transformation used for drawing x-axis labels, ticks 

660 and gridlines. The x-direction is in data coordinates and the 

661 y-direction is in axis coordinates. 

662 

663 .. note:: 

664 

665 This transformation is primarily used by the 

666 :class:`~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be 

667 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to 

668 place axis elements in different locations. 

669 

670 """ 

671 if which == 'grid': 

672 return self._xaxis_transform 

673 elif which == 'tick1': 

674 # for cartesian projection, this is bottom spine 

675 return self.spines['bottom'].get_spine_transform() 

676 elif which == 'tick2': 

677 # for cartesian projection, this is top spine 

678 return self.spines['top'].get_spine_transform() 

679 else: 

680 raise ValueError('unknown value for which') 

681 

682 def get_xaxis_text1_transform(self, pad_points): 

683 """ 

684 Get the transformation used for drawing x-axis labels, which 

685 will add the given amount of padding (in points) between the 

686 axes and the label. The x-direction is in data coordinates 

687 and the y-direction is in axis coordinates. Returns a 

688 3-tuple of the form:: 

689 

690 (transform, valign, halign) 

691 

692 where *valign* and *halign* are requested alignments for the 

693 text. 

694 

695 .. note:: 

696 

697 This transformation is primarily used by the 

698 :class:`~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be 

699 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to 

700 place axis elements in different locations. 

701 

702 """ 

703 labels_align = matplotlib.rcParams["xtick.alignment"] 

704 

705 return (self.get_xaxis_transform(which='tick1') + 

706 mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(0, -1 * pad_points / 72, 

707 self.figure.dpi_scale_trans), 

708 "top", labels_align) 

709 

710 def get_xaxis_text2_transform(self, pad_points): 

711 """ 

712 Get the transformation used for drawing the secondary x-axis 

713 labels, which will add the given amount of padding (in points) 

714 between the axes and the label. The x-direction is in data 

715 coordinates and the y-direction is in axis coordinates. 

716 Returns a 3-tuple of the form:: 

717 

718 (transform, valign, halign) 

719 

720 where *valign* and *halign* are requested alignments for the 

721 text. 

722 

723 .. note:: 

724 

725 This transformation is primarily used by the 

726 :class:`~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be 

727 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to 

728 place axis elements in different locations. 

729 

730 """ 

731 labels_align = matplotlib.rcParams["xtick.alignment"] 

732 return (self.get_xaxis_transform(which='tick2') + 

733 mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(0, pad_points / 72, 

734 self.figure.dpi_scale_trans), 

735 "bottom", labels_align) 

736

817 def _update_transScale(self): 

818 self.transScale.set( 

819 mtransforms.blended_transform_factory( 

820 self.xaxis.get_transform(), self.yaxis.get_transform())) 

821 for line in getattr(self, "lines", []): # Not set during init. 

822 try: 

823 line._transformed_path.invalidate() 

824 except AttributeError: 

825 pass 

826 

827 def get_position(self, original=False): 

828 """ 

829 Get a copy of the axes rectangle as a `.Bbox`. 

830 

831 Parameters 

832 ---------- 

833 original : bool 

834 If ``True``, return the original position. Otherwise return the 

835 active position. For an explanation of the positions see 

836 `.set_position`. 

837 

838 Returns 

839 ------- 

840 pos : `.Bbox` 

841 

842 """ 

843 if original: 

844 return self._originalPosition.frozen() 

845 else: 

846 locator = self.get_axes_locator() 

847 if not locator: 

848 self.apply_aspect() 

849 return self._position.frozen() 

850 

851 def set_position(self, pos, which='both'): 

852 """ 

853 Set the axes position. 

854 

855 Axes have two position attributes. The 'original' position is the 

856 position allocated for the Axes. The 'active' position is the 

857 position the Axes is actually drawn at. These positions are usually 

858 the same unless a fixed aspect is set to the Axes. See `.set_aspect` 

859 for details. 

860 

861 Parameters 

862 ---------- 

863 pos : [left, bottom, width, height] or `~matplotlib.transforms.Bbox` 

864 The new position of the in `.Figure` coordinates. 

865 

866 which : {'both', 'active', 'original'}, optional 

867 Determines which position variables to change. 

868 

869 """ 

870 self._set_position(pos, which=which) 

871 # because this is being called externally to the library we 

872 # zero the constrained layout parts. 

873 self._layoutbox = None 

874 self._poslayoutbox = None 

875 

876 def _set_position(self, pos, which='both'): 

877 """ 

878 private version of set_position. Call this internally 

879 to get the same functionality of `get_position`, but not 

880 to take the axis out of the constrained_layout 

881 hierarchy. 

882 """ 

883 if not isinstance(pos, mtransforms.BboxBase): 

884 pos = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(*pos) 

885 for ax in self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self): 

886 if which in ('both', 'active'): 

887 ax._position.set(pos) 

888 if which in ('both', 'original'): 

889 ax._originalPosition.set(pos) 

890 self.stale = True 

891 

892 def reset_position(self): 

893 """ 

894 Reset the active position to the original position. 

895 

896 This resets the a possible position change due to aspect constraints. 

897 For an explanation of the positions see `.set_position`. 

898 """ 

899 for ax in self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self): 

900 pos = ax.get_position(original=True) 

901 ax.set_position(pos, which='active') 

902

904 """ 

905 Set the axes locator. 

906 

907 Parameters 

908 ---------- 

909 locator : Callable[[Axes, Renderer], Bbox] 

910 """ 

911 self._axes_locator = locator 

912 self.stale = True 

913 

914 def get_axes_locator(self): 

915 """ 

916 Return the axes_locator. 

917 """ 

918 return self._axes_locator

920 def _set_artist_props(self, a): 

921 """set the boilerplate props for artists added to axes""" 

922 a.set_figure(self.figure) 

923 if not a.is_transform_set(): 

924 a.set_transform(self.transData) 

925 

926 a.axes = self 

927 if a.mouseover: 

928 self._mouseover_set.add(a) 

929 

930 def _gen_axes_patch(self): 

931 """ 

932 Returns the patch used to draw the background of the axes. It 

933 is also used as the clipping path for any data elements on the 

934 axes. 

935 

936 In the standard axes, this is a rectangle, but in other 

937 projections it may not be. 

938 

939 .. note:: 

940 

941 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

942 

943 """ 

944 return mpatches.Rectangle((0.0, 0.0), 1.0, 1.0) 

945 

946 def _gen_axes_spines(self, locations=None, offset=0.0, units='inches'): 

947 """ 

948 Returns a dict whose keys are spine names and values are 

949 Line2D or Patch instances. Each element is used to draw a 

950 spine of the axes. 

951 

952 In the standard axes, this is a single line segment, but in 

953 other projections it may not be. 

954 

955 .. note:: 

956 

957 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

958 

959 """ 

960 return OrderedDict((side, mspines.Spine.linear_spine(self, side)) 

961 for side in ['left', 'right', 'bottom', 'top']) 

962 

963 def cla(self): 

964 """Clear the current axes.""" 

965 # Note: this is called by Axes.__init__() 

966 

967 # stash the current visibility state 

968 if hasattr(self, 'patch'): 

969 patch_visible = self.patch.get_visible() 

970 else: 

971 patch_visible = True 

972 

973 xaxis_visible = self.xaxis.get_visible() 

974 yaxis_visible = self.yaxis.get_visible() 

975 

976 self.xaxis.cla() 

977 self.yaxis.cla() 

978 

979 for name, spine in self.spines.items(): 

980 spine.cla() 

981 

982 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = True 

983 self.callbacks = cbook.CallbackRegistry() 

984 

985 if self._sharex is not None: 

986 # major and minor are axis.Ticker class instances with 

987 # locator and formatter attributes 

988 self.xaxis.major = self._sharex.xaxis.major 

989 self.xaxis.minor = self._sharex.xaxis.minor 

990 x0, x1 = self._sharex.get_xlim() 

991 self.set_xlim(x0, x1, emit=False, 

992 auto=self._sharex.get_autoscalex_on()) 

993 self.xaxis._scale = mscale.scale_factory( 

994 self._sharex.xaxis.get_scale(), self.xaxis) 

995 else: 

996 self.xaxis._set_scale('linear') 

997 try: 

998 self.set_xlim(0, 1) 

999 except TypeError: 

1000 pass 

1001 

1002 if self._sharey is not None: 

1003 self.yaxis.major = self._sharey.yaxis.major 

1004 self.yaxis.minor = self._sharey.yaxis.minor 

1005 y0, y1 = self._sharey.get_ylim() 

1006 self.set_ylim(y0, y1, emit=False, 

1007 auto=self._sharey.get_autoscaley_on()) 

1008 self.yaxis._scale = mscale.scale_factory( 

1009 self._sharey.yaxis.get_scale(), self.yaxis) 

1010 else: 

1011 self.yaxis._set_scale('linear') 

1012 try: 

1013 self.set_ylim(0, 1) 

1014 except TypeError: 

1015 pass 

1016 # update the minor locator for x and y axis based on rcParams 

1017 if rcParams['xtick.minor.visible']: 

1018 self.xaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator()) 

1019 

1020 if rcParams['ytick.minor.visible']: 

1021 self.yaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator()) 

1022 

1023 if self._sharex is None: 

1024 self._autoscaleXon = True 

1025 if self._sharey is None: 

1026 self._autoscaleYon = True 

1027 self._xmargin = rcParams['axes.xmargin'] 

1028 self._ymargin = rcParams['axes.ymargin'] 

1029 self._tight = None 

1030 self._use_sticky_edges = True 

1031 self._update_transScale() # needed? 

1032 

1033 self._get_lines = _process_plot_var_args(self) 

1034 self._get_patches_for_fill = _process_plot_var_args(self, 'fill') 

1035 

1036 self._gridOn = rcParams['axes.grid'] 

1037 self.lines = [] 

1038 self.patches = [] 

1039 self.texts = [] 

1040 self.tables = [] 

1041 self.artists = [] 

1042 self.images = [] 

1043 self._mouseover_set = _OrderedSet() 

1044 self.child_axes = [] 

1045 self._current_image = None # strictly for pyplot via _sci, _gci 

1046 self.legend_ = None 

1047 self.collections = [] # collection.Collection instances 

1048 self.containers = [] 

1049 

1050 self.grid(False) # Disable grid on init to use rcParameter 

1051 self.grid(self._gridOn, which=rcParams['axes.grid.which'], 

1052 axis=rcParams['axes.grid.axis']) 

1053 props = font_manager.FontProperties( 

1054 size=rcParams['axes.titlesize'], 

1055 weight=rcParams['axes.titleweight']) 

1056 

1057 self.title = mtext.Text( 

1058 x=0.5, y=1.0, text='', 

1059 fontproperties=props, 

1060 verticalalignment='baseline', 

1061 horizontalalignment='center', 

1062 ) 

1063 self._left_title = mtext.Text( 

1064 x=0.0, y=1.0, text='', 

1065 fontproperties=props.copy(), 

1066 verticalalignment='baseline', 

1067 horizontalalignment='left', ) 

1068 self._right_title = mtext.Text( 

1069 x=1.0, y=1.0, text='', 

1070 fontproperties=props.copy(), 

1071 verticalalignment='baseline', 

1072 horizontalalignment='right', 

1073 ) 

1074 title_offset_points = rcParams['axes.titlepad'] 

1075 # refactor this out so it can be called in ax.set_title if 

1076 # pad argument used... 

1077 self._set_title_offset_trans(title_offset_points) 

1078 # determine if the title position has been set manually: 

1079 self._autotitlepos = None 

1080 

1081 for _title in (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title): 

1082 self._set_artist_props(_title) 

1083 

1084 # The patch draws the background of the axes. We want this to be below 

1085 # the other artists. We use the frame to draw the edges so we are 

1086 # setting the edgecolor to None. 

1087 self.patch = self._gen_axes_patch() 

1088 self.patch.set_figure(self.figure) 

1089 self.patch.set_facecolor(self._facecolor) 

1090 self.patch.set_edgecolor('None') 

1091 self.patch.set_linewidth(0) 

1092 self.patch.set_transform(self.transAxes) 

1093 

1094 self.set_axis_on() 

1095 

1096 self.xaxis.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1097 self.yaxis.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1098 

1099 self._shared_x_axes.clean() 

1100 self._shared_y_axes.clean() 

1101 if self._sharex: 

1102 self.xaxis.set_visible(xaxis_visible) 

1103 self.patch.set_visible(patch_visible) 

1104 

1105 if self._sharey: 

1106 self.yaxis.set_visible(yaxis_visible) 

1107 self.patch.set_visible(patch_visible) 

1108 

1109 self.stale = True 

1110 

1111 @property 

1112 @cbook.deprecated("3.0") 

1113 def mouseover_set(self): 

1114 return frozenset(self._mouseover_set) 

1115 

1116 def clear(self): 

1117 """Clear the axes.""" 

1118 self.cla() 

1119

1121 """Get the facecolor of the Axes.""" 

1122 return self.patch.get_facecolor() 

1123 get_fc = get_facecolor

1128 

1129 Parameters

1138 def _set_title_offset_trans(self, title_offset_points): 

1139 """ 

1140 Set the offset for the title either from rcParams['axes.titlepad'] 

1141 or from set_title kwarg ``pad``. 

1142 """ 

1143 self.titleOffsetTrans = mtransforms.ScaledTranslation( 

1144 0.0, title_offset_points / 72, 

1145 self.figure.dpi_scale_trans) 

1146 for _title in (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title): 

1147 _title.set_transform(self.transAxes + self.titleOffsetTrans) 

1148 _title.set_clip_box(None)

1150 def set_prop_cycle(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1151 """ 

1152 Set the property cycle of the Axes. 

1153 

1154 The property cycle controls the style properties such as color, 

1155 marker and linestyle of future plot commands. The style properties 

1156 of data already added to the Axes are not modified. 

1157 

1158 Call signatures:: 

1159 

1160 set_prop_cycle(cycler) 

1161 set_prop_cycle(label=values[, label2=values2[, ...]]) 

1162 set_prop_cycle(label, values) 

1163 

1164 Form 1 sets given `~cycler.Cycler` object. 

1165 

1166 Form 2 creates a `~cycler.Cycler` which cycles over one or more 

1167 properties simultaneously and set it as the property cycle of the 

1168 axes. If multiple properties are given, their value lists must have 

1169 the same length. This is just a shortcut for explicitly creating a 

1170 cycler and passing it to the function, i.e. it's short for 

1171 ``set_prop_cycle(cycler(label=values label2=values2, ...))``. 

1172 

1173 Form 3 creates a `~cycler.Cycler` for a single property and set it 

1174 as the property cycle of the axes. This form exists for compatibility 

1175 with the original `cycler.cycler` interface. Its use is discouraged 

1176 in favor of the kwarg form, i.e. ``set_prop_cycle(label=values)``. 

1177 

1178 Parameters 

1179 ---------- 

1180 cycler : Cycler 

1181 Set the given Cycler. *None* resets to the cycle defined by the 

1182 current style. 

1183 

1184 label : str 

1185 The property key. Must be a valid `.Artist` property. 

1186 For example, 'color' or 'linestyle'. Aliases are allowed, 

1187 such as 'c' for 'color' and 'lw' for 'linewidth'. 

1188 

1189 values : iterable 

1190 Finite-length iterable of the property values. These values 

1191 are validated and will raise a ValueError if invalid. 

1192 

1193 Examples 

1194 -------- 

1195 Setting the property cycle for a single property: 

1196 

1197 >>> ax.set_prop_cycle(color=['red', 'green', 'blue']) 

1198 

1199 Setting the property cycle for simultaneously cycling over multiple 

1200 properties (e.g. red circle, green plus, blue cross): 

1201 

1202 >>> ax.set_prop_cycle(color=['red', 'green', 'blue'], 

1203 ... marker=['o', '+', 'x']) 

1204 

1205 See Also 

1206 -------- 

1207 matplotlib.rcsetup.cycler 

1208 Convenience function for creating validated cyclers for properties. 

1209 cycler.cycler 

1210 The original function for creating unvalidated cyclers. 

1211 

1212 """ 

1213 if args and kwargs: 

1214 raise TypeError("Cannot supply both positional and keyword " 

1215 "arguments to this method.") 

1216 # Can't do `args == (None,)` as that crashes cycler. 

1217 if len(args) == 1 and args[0] is None: 

1218 prop_cycle = None 

1219 else: 

1220 prop_cycle = cycler(*args, **kwargs) 

1221 self._get_lines.set_prop_cycle(prop_cycle) 

1222 self._get_patches_for_fill.set_prop_cycle(prop_cycle) 

1223 

1224 def get_aspect(self): 

1225 return self._aspect 

1226 

1227 def set_aspect(self, aspect, adjustable=None, anchor=None, share=False): 

1228 """ 

1229 Set the aspect of the axis scaling, i.e. the ratio of y-unit to x-unit. 

1230 

1231 Parameters 

1232 ---------- 

1233 aspect : {'auto', 'equal'} or num 

1234 Possible values: 

1235 

1236 ======== ================================================ 

1237 value description 

1238 ======== ================================================ 

1239 'auto' automatic; fill the position rectangle with data 

1240 'equal' same scaling from data to plot units for x and y 

1241 num a circle will be stretched such that the height 

1242 is num times the width. aspect=1 is the same as 

1243 aspect='equal'. 

1244 ======== ================================================ 

1245 

1246 adjustable : None or {'box', 'datalim'}, optional 

1247 If not ``None``, this defines which parameter will be adjusted to 

1248 meet the required aspect. See `.set_adjustable` for further 

1249 details. 

1250 

1251 anchor : None or str or 2-tuple of float, optional 

1252 If not ``None``, this defines where the Axes will be drawn if there 

1253 is extra space due to aspect constraints. The most common way to 

1254 to specify the anchor are abbreviations of cardinal directions: 

1255 

1256 ===== ===================== 

1257 value description 

1258 ===== ===================== 

1259 'C' centered 

1260 'SW' lower left corner 

1261 'S' middle of bottom edge 

1262 'SE' lower right corner 

1263 etc. 

1264 ===== ===================== 

1265 

1266 See `.set_anchor` for further details. 

1267 

1268 share : bool, optional 

1269 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes. 

1270 Default is ``False``. 

1271 

1272 See Also 

1273 -------- 

1274 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable 

1275 defining the parameter to adjust in order to meet the required 

1276 aspect. 

1277 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor 

1278 defining the position in case of extra space. 

1279 """ 

1280 if not (isinstance(aspect, str) and aspect in ('equal', 'auto')): 

1281 aspect = float(aspect) # raise ValueError if necessary 

1282 if share: 

1283 axes = set(self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self) 

1284 + self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self)) 

1285 else: 

1286 axes = [self] 

1287 for ax in axes: 

1288 ax._aspect = aspect 

1289 

1290 if adjustable is None: 

1291 adjustable = self._adjustable 

1292 self.set_adjustable(adjustable, share=share) # Handle sharing. 

1293 

1294 if anchor is not None: 

1295 self.set_anchor(anchor, share=share) 

1296 self.stale = True 

1297 

1298 def get_adjustable(self): 

1299 return self._adjustable 

1300 

1301 def set_adjustable(self, adjustable, share=False): 

1302 """ 

1303 Define which parameter the Axes will change to achieve a given aspect. 

1304 

1305 Parameters 

1306 ---------- 

1307 adjustable : {'box', 'datalim'} 

1308 If 'box', change the physical dimensions of the Axes. 

1309 If 'datalim', change the ``x`` or ``y`` data limits. 

1310 

1311 share : bool, optional 

1312 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes. 

1313 Default is ``False``. 

1314 

1315 See Also 

1316 -------- 

1317 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1318 for a description of aspect handling. 

1319 

1320 Notes 

1321 ----- 

1322 Shared Axes (of which twinned Axes are a special case) 

1323 impose restrictions on how aspect ratios can be imposed. 

1324 For twinned Axes, use 'datalim'. For Axes that share both 

1325 x and y, use 'box'. Otherwise, either 'datalim' or 'box' 

1326 may be used. These limitations are partly a requirement 

1327 to avoid over-specification, and partly a result of the 

1328 particular implementation we are currently using, in 

1329 which the adjustments for aspect ratios are done sequentially 

1330 and independently on each Axes as it is drawn. 

1331 """ 

1332 if adjustable == 'box-forced': 

1333 cbook.warn_deprecated( 

1334 "2.2", "box-forced", obj_type="keyword argument") 

1335 if adjustable not in ('box', 'datalim', 'box-forced'): 

1336 raise ValueError("argument must be 'box', or 'datalim'") 

1337 if share: 

1338 axes = set(self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self) 

1339 + self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self)) 

1340 else: 

1341 axes = [self] 

1342 for ax in axes: 

1343 ax._adjustable = adjustable 

1344 self.stale = True 

1345 

1346 def get_anchor(self): 

1347 """ 

1348 Get the anchor location. 

1349 

1350 See Also 

1351 -------- 

1352 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor 

1353 for a description of the anchor. 

1354 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1355 for a description of aspect handling. 

1356 """ 

1357 return self._anchor 

1358 

1359 def set_anchor(self, anchor, share=False): 

1360 """ 

1361 Define the anchor location. 

1362 

1363 The actual drawing area (active position) of the Axes may be smaller 

1364 than the Bbox (original position) when a fixed aspect is required. The 

1365 anchor defines where the drawing area will be located within the 

1366 available space. 

1367 

1368 Parameters 

1369 ---------- 

1370 anchor : 2-tuple of floats or {'C', 'SW', 'S', 'SE', ...} 

1371 The anchor position may be either: 

1372 

1373 - a sequence (*cx*, *cy*). *cx* and *cy* may range from 0 

1374 to 1, where 0 is left or bottom and 1 is right or top. 

1375 

1376 - a string using cardinal directions as abbreviation: 

1377 

1378 - 'C' for centered 

1379 - 'S' (south) for bottom-center 

1380 - 'SW' (south west) for bottom-left 

1381 - etc. 

1382 

1383 Here is an overview of the possible positions: 

1384 

1385 +------+------+------+ 

1386 | 'NW' | 'N' | 'NE' | 

1387 +------+------+------+ 

1388 | 'W' | 'C' | 'E' | 

1389 +------+------+------+ 

1390 | 'SW' | 'S' | 'SE' | 

1391 +------+------+------+ 

1392 

1393 share : bool, optional 

1394 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes. 

1395 Default is ``False``. 

1396 

1397 See Also 

1398 -------- 

1399 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1400 for a description of aspect handling. 

1401 """ 

1402 if not (anchor in mtransforms.Bbox.coefs or len(anchor) == 2): 

1403 raise ValueError('argument must be among %s' % 

1404 ', '.join(mtransforms.Bbox.coefs)) 

1405 if share: 

1406 axes = set(self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self) 

1407 + self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self)) 

1408 else: 

1409 axes = [self] 

1410 for ax in axes: 

1411 ax._anchor = anchor 

1412 

1413 self.stale = True 

1414 

1415 def get_data_ratio(self): 

1416 """ 

1417 Returns the aspect ratio of the raw data. 

1418 

1419 This method is intended to be overridden by new projection 

1420 types. 

1421 """ 

1422 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

1423 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

1424 

1425 xsize = max(abs(xmax - xmin), 1e-30) 

1426 ysize = max(abs(ymax - ymin), 1e-30) 

1427 

1428 return ysize / xsize 

1429 

1430 def get_data_ratio_log(self): 

1431 """ 

1432 Returns the aspect ratio of the raw data in log scale. 

1433 Will be used when both axis scales are in log. 

1434 """ 

1435 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

1436 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

1437 

1438 xsize = max(abs(math.log10(xmax) - math.log10(xmin)), 1e-30) 

1439 ysize = max(abs(math.log10(ymax) - math.log10(ymin)), 1e-30) 

1440 

1441 return ysize / xsize 

1442 

1443 def apply_aspect(self, position=None): 

1444 """ 

1445 Adjust the Axes for a specified data aspect ratio. 

1446 

1447 Depending on `.get_adjustable` this will modify either the Axes box 

1448 (position) or the view limits. In the former case, `.get_anchor` 

1449 will affect the position. 

1450 

1451 Notes 

1452 ----- 

1453 This is called automatically when each Axes is drawn. You may need 

1454 to call it yourself if you need to update the Axes position and/or 

1455 view limits before the Figure is drawn. 

1456 

1457 See Also 

1458 -------- 

1459 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1460 for a description of aspect ratio handling. 

1461 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable 

1462 defining the parameter to adjust in order to meet the required 

1463 aspect. 

1464 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor 

1465 defining the position in case of extra space. 

1466 """ 

1467 if position is None: 

1468 position = self.get_position(original=True) 

1469 

1470 aspect = self.get_aspect() 

1471 

1472 if self.name != 'polar': 

1473 xscale, yscale = self.get_xscale(), self.get_yscale() 

1474 if xscale == "linear" and yscale == "linear": 

1475 aspect_scale_mode = "linear" 

1476 elif xscale == "log" and yscale == "log": 

1477 aspect_scale_mode = "log" 

1478 elif ((xscale == "linear" and yscale == "log") or 

1479 (xscale == "log" and yscale == "linear")): 

1480 if aspect != "auto": 

1481 warnings.warn( 

1482 'aspect is not supported for Axes with xscale=%s, ' 

1483 'yscale=%s' % (xscale, yscale), stacklevel=2) 

1484 aspect = "auto" 

1485 else: # some custom projections have their own scales. 

1486 pass 

1487 else: 

1488 aspect_scale_mode = "linear" 

1489 

1490 if aspect == 'auto': 

1491 self._set_position(position, which='active') 

1492 return 

1493 

1494 if aspect == 'equal': 

1495 A = 1 

1496 else: 

1497 A = aspect 

1498 

1499 figW, figH = self.get_figure().get_size_inches() 

1500 fig_aspect = figH / figW 

1501 if self._adjustable in ['box', 'box-forced']: 

1502 if self in self._twinned_axes: 

1503 raise RuntimeError("Adjustable 'box' is not allowed in a" 

1504 " twinned Axes. Use 'datalim' instead.") 

1505 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1506 box_aspect = A * self.get_data_ratio_log() 

1507 else: 

1508 box_aspect = A * self.get_data_ratio() 

1509 pb = position.frozen() 

1510 pb1 = pb.shrunk_to_aspect(box_aspect, pb, fig_aspect) 

1511 self._set_position(pb1.anchored(self.get_anchor(), pb), 'active') 

1512 return 

1513 

1514 # reset active to original in case it had been changed 

1515 # by prior use of 'box' 

1516 self._set_position(position, which='active') 

1517 

1518 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

1519 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

1520 

1521 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1522 xmin, xmax = math.log10(xmin), math.log10(xmax) 

1523 ymin, ymax = math.log10(ymin), math.log10(ymax) 

1524 

1525 xsize = max(abs(xmax - xmin), 1e-30) 

1526 ysize = max(abs(ymax - ymin), 1e-30) 

1527 

1528 l, b, w, h = position.bounds 

1529 box_aspect = fig_aspect * (h / w) 

1530 data_ratio = box_aspect / A 

1531 

1532 y_expander = (data_ratio * xsize / ysize - 1.0) 

1533 # If y_expander > 0, the dy/dx viewLim ratio needs to increase 

1534 if abs(y_expander) < 0.005: 

1535 return 

1536 

1537 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1538 dL = self.dataLim 

1539 dL_width = math.log10(dL.x1) - math.log10(dL.x0) 

1540 dL_height = math.log10(dL.y1) - math.log10(dL.y0) 

1541 xr = 1.05 * dL_width 

1542 yr = 1.05 * dL_height 

1543 else: 

1544 dL = self.dataLim 

1545 xr = 1.05 * dL.width 

1546 yr = 1.05 * dL.height 

1547 

1548 xmarg = xsize - xr 

1549 ymarg = ysize - yr 

1550 Ysize = data_ratio * xsize 

1551 Xsize = ysize / data_ratio 

1552 Xmarg = Xsize - xr 

1553 Ymarg = Ysize - yr 

1554 # Setting these targets to, e.g., 0.05*xr does not seem to 

1555 # help. 

1556 xm = 0 

1557 ym = 0 

1558 

1559 shared_x = self in self._shared_x_axes 

1560 shared_y = self in self._shared_y_axes 

1561 # Not sure whether we need this check: 

1562 if shared_x and shared_y: 

1563 raise RuntimeError("adjustable='datalim' is not allowed when both" 

1564 " axes are shared.") 

1565 

1566 # If y is shared, then we are only allowed to change x, etc. 

1567 if shared_y: 

1568 adjust_y = False 

1569 else: 

1570 if xmarg > xm and ymarg > ym: 

1571 adjy = ((Ymarg > 0 and y_expander < 0) or 

1572 (Xmarg < 0 and y_expander > 0)) 

1573 else: 

1574 adjy = y_expander > 0 

1575 adjust_y = shared_x or adjy # (Ymarg > xmarg) 

1576 

1577 if adjust_y: 

1578 yc = 0.5 * (ymin + ymax) 

1579 y0 = yc - Ysize / 2.0 

1580 y1 = yc + Ysize / 2.0 

1581 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1582 self.set_ybound((10. ** y0, 10. ** y1)) 

1583 else: 

1584 self.set_ybound((y0, y1)) 

1585 else: 

1586 xc = 0.5 * (xmin + xmax) 

1587 x0 = xc - Xsize / 2.0 

1588 x1 = xc + Xsize / 2.0 

1589 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1590 self.set_xbound((10. ** x0, 10. ** x1)) 

1591 else: 

1592 self.set_xbound((x0, x1)) 

1593 

1594 def axis(self, *v, **kwargs): 

1595 """ 

1596 Convenience method to get or set some axis properties. 

1597 

1598 Call signatures:: 

1599 

1600 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis() 

1601 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) 

1602 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(option) 

1603 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(**kwargs) 

1604 

1605 Parameters 

1606 ---------- 

1607 xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax : float, optional 

1608 The axis limits to be set. Either none or all of the limits must 

1609 be given. 

1610 

1611 option : str 

1612 Possible values: 

1613 

1614 ======== ========================================================== 

1615 Value Description 

1616 ======== ========================================================== 

1617 'on' Turn on axis lines and labels. 

1618 'off' Turn off axis lines and labels. 

1619 'equal' Set equal scaling (i.e., make circles circular) by 

1620 changing axis limits. 

1621 'scaled' Set equal scaling (i.e., make circles circular) by 

1622 changing dimensions of the plot box. 

1623 'tight' Set limits just large enough to show all data. 

1624 'auto' Automatic scaling (fill plot box with data). 

1625 'normal' Same as 'auto'; deprecated. 

1626 'image' 'scaled' with axis limits equal to data limits. 

1627 'square' Square plot; similar to 'scaled', but initially forcing 

1628 ``xmax-xmin = ymax-ymin``. 

1629 ======== ========================================================== 

1630 

1631 emit : bool, optional, default *True* 

1632 Whether observers are notified of the axis limit change. 

1633 This option is passed on to `~.Axes.set_xlim` and 

1634 `~.Axes.set_ylim`. 

1635 

1636 Returns 

1637 ------- 

1638 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax : float 

1639 The axis limits. 

1640 

1641 See also 

1642 -------- 

1643 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_xlim 

1644 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_ylim 

1645 """ 

1646 

1647 if len(v) == len(kwargs) == 0: 

1648 xmin, xmax = self.get_xlim() 

1649 ymin, ymax = self.get_ylim() 

1650 return xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax 

1651 

1652 emit = kwargs.get('emit', True) 

1653 

1654 if len(v) == 1 and isinstance(v[0], str): 

1655 s = v[0].lower() 

1656 if s == 'on': 

1657 self.set_axis_on() 

1658 elif s == 'off': 

1659 self.set_axis_off() 

1660 elif s in ('equal', 'tight', 'scaled', 'normal', 

1661 'auto', 'image', 'square'): 

1662 self.set_autoscale_on(True) 

1663 self.set_aspect('auto') 

1664 self.autoscale_view(tight=False) 

1665 # self.apply_aspect() 

1666 if s == 'equal': 

1667 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='datalim') 

1668 elif s == 'scaled': 

1669 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C') 

1670 self.set_autoscale_on(False) # Req. by Mark Bakker 

1671 elif s == 'tight': 

1672 self.autoscale_view(tight=True) 

1673 self.set_autoscale_on(False) 

1674 elif s == 'image': 

1675 self.autoscale_view(tight=True) 

1676 self.set_autoscale_on(False) 

1677 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C') 

1678 elif s == 'square': 

1679 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C') 

1680 self.set_autoscale_on(False) 

1681 xlim = self.get_xlim() 

1682 ylim = self.get_ylim() 

1683 edge_size = max(np.diff(xlim), np.diff(ylim)) 

1684 self.set_xlim([xlim[0], xlim[0] + edge_size], 

1685 emit=emit, auto=False) 

1686 self.set_ylim([ylim[0], ylim[0] + edge_size], 

1687 emit=emit, auto=False) 

1688 else: 

1689 raise ValueError('Unrecognized string %s to axis; ' 

1690 'try on or off' % s) 

1691 xmin, xmax = self.get_xlim() 

1692 ymin, ymax = self.get_ylim() 

1693 return xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax 

1694 

1695 try: 

1696 v[0] 

1697 except IndexError: 

1698 xmin = kwargs.get('xmin', None) 

1699 xmax = kwargs.get('xmax', None) 

1700 auto = False # turn off autoscaling, unless... 

1701 if xmin is None and xmax is None: 

1702 auto = None # leave autoscaling state alone 

1703 xmin, xmax = self.set_xlim(xmin, xmax, emit=emit, auto=auto) 

1704 

1705 ymin = kwargs.get('ymin', None) 

1706 ymax = kwargs.get('ymax', None) 

1707 auto = False # turn off autoscaling, unless... 

1708 if ymin is None and ymax is None: 

1709 auto = None # leave autoscaling state alone 

1710 ymin, ymax = self.set_ylim(ymin, ymax, emit=emit, auto=auto) 

1711 return xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax 

1712 

1713 v = v[0] 

1714 if len(v) != 4: 

1715 raise ValueError('v must contain [xmin xmax ymin ymax]') 

1716 

1717 self.set_xlim([v[0], v[1]], emit=emit, auto=False) 

1718 self.set_ylim([v[2], v[3]], emit=emit, auto=False) 

1719 

1720 return v 

1721

1764 def _sci(self, im): 

1765 """Set the current image. 

1766 

1767 This image will be the target of colormap functions like 

1768 `~.pyplot.viridis`, and other functions such as `~.pyplot.clim`. The 

1769 current image is an attribute of the current axes. 

1770 """ 

1771 if isinstance(im, matplotlib.contour.ContourSet): 

1772 if im.collections[0] not in self.collections: 

1773 raise ValueError("ContourSet must be in current Axes") 

1774 elif im not in self.images and im not in self.collections: 

1775 raise ValueError("Argument must be an image, collection, or " 

1776 "ContourSet in this Axes") 

1777 self._current_image = im

1795 len(self.collections) + 

1796 len(self.images) +

1798 len(self.patches)) > 0

1800 def add_artist(self, a): 

1801 """Add any :class:`~matplotlib.artist.Artist` to the axes. 

1802 

1803 Use `add_artist` only for artists for which there is no dedicated 

1804 "add" method; and if necessary, use a method such as `update_datalim` 

1805 to manually update the dataLim if the artist is to be included in 

1806 autoscaling. 

1807 

1808 If no ``transform`` has been specified when creating the artist (e.g. 

1809 ``artist.get_transform() == None``) then the transform is set to 

1810 ``ax.transData``. 

1811 

1812 Returns the artist. 

1813 """ 

1814 a.axes = self 

1815 self.artists.append(a) 

1816 a._remove_method = self.artists.remove 

1817 self._set_artist_props(a) 

1818 a.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1819 self.stale = True 

1820 return a

1822 def add_child_axes(self, ax): 

1823 """ 

1824 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.axes.Axesbase` instance 

1825 as a child to the axes. 

1826 

1827 Returns the added axes. 

1828 

1829 This is the lowlevel version. See `.axes.Axes.inset_axes` 

1830 """ 

1831 

1832 # normally axes have themselves as the axes, but these need to have 

1833 # their parent... 

1834 # Need to bypass the getter... 

1835 ax._axes = self 

1836 ax.stale_callback = martist._stale_axes_callback 

1837 

1838 self.child_axes.append(ax) 

1839 ax._remove_method = self.child_axes.remove 

1840 self.stale = True 

1841 return ax

1843 def add_collection(self, collection, autolim=True): 

1844 """ 

1845 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.collections.Collection` instance 

1846 to the axes. 

1847 

1848 Returns the collection. 

1849 """ 

1850 label = collection.get_label() 

1851 if not label: 

1852 collection.set_label('_collection%d' % len(self.collections)) 

1853 self.collections.append(collection) 

1854 collection._remove_method = self.collections.remove 

1855 self._set_artist_props(collection) 

1856 

1857 if collection.get_clip_path() is None: 

1858 collection.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1859 

1860 if autolim: 

1861 self.update_datalim(collection.get_datalim(self.transData)) 

1862 

1863 self.stale = True 

1864 return collection

1866 def add_image(self, image):

1869 

1870 Returns the image. 

1871 """ 

1872 self._set_artist_props(image) 

1873 if not image.get_label(): 

1874 image.set_label('_image%d' % len(self.images)) 

1875 self.images.append(image) 

1876 image._remove_method = self.images.remove 

1877 self.stale = True

1882 self.axes.update_datalim(((xmin, ymin), (xmax, ymax)))

1884 def add_line(self, line): 

1885 """ 

1886 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` to the list of plot 

1887 lines 

1888 

1889 Returns the line. 

1890 """ 

1891 self._set_artist_props(line) 

1892 if line.get_clip_path() is None: 

1893 line.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1894 

1895 self._update_line_limits(line) 

1896 if not line.get_label(): 

1897 line.set_label('_line%d' % len(self.lines)) 

1898 self.lines.append(line) 

1899 line._remove_method = self.lines.remove 

1900 self.stale = True 

1901 return line

1912 

1913 def _update_line_limits(self, line): 

1914 """ 

1915 Figures out the data limit of the given line, updating self.dataLim. 

1916 """ 

1917 path = line.get_path() 

1918 if path.vertices.size == 0: 

1919 return 

1920 

1921 line_trans = line.get_transform() 

1922 

1923 if line_trans == self.transData: 

1924 data_path = path 

1925 

1926 elif any(line_trans.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)): 

1927 # identify the transform to go from line's coordinates 

1928 # to data coordinates 

1929 trans_to_data = line_trans - self.transData 

1930 

1931 # if transData is affine we can use the cached non-affine component 

1932 # of line's path. (since the non-affine part of line_trans is 

1933 # entirely encapsulated in trans_to_data). 

1934 if self.transData.is_affine: 

1935 line_trans_path = line._get_transformed_path() 

1936 na_path, _ = line_trans_path.get_transformed_path_and_affine() 

1937 data_path = trans_to_data.transform_path_affine(na_path) 

1938 else: 

1939 data_path = trans_to_data.transform_path(path) 

1940 else: 

1941 # for backwards compatibility we update the dataLim with the 

1942 # coordinate range of the given path, even though the coordinate 

1943 # systems are completely different. This may occur in situations 

1944 # such as when ax.transAxes is passed through for absolute 

1945 # positioning. 

1946 data_path = path 

1947 

1948 if data_path.vertices.size > 0: 

1949 updatex, updatey = line_trans.contains_branch_seperately( 

1950 self.transData) 

1951 self.dataLim.update_from_path(data_path, 

1952 self.ignore_existing_data_limits, 

1953 updatex=updatex, 

1954 updatey=updatey) 

1955 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = False 

1956 

1957 def add_patch(self, p): 

1958 """ 

1959 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.patches.Patch` *p* to the list of 

1960 axes patches; the clipbox will be set to the Axes clipping 

1961 box. If the transform is not set, it will be set to 

1962 :attr:`transData`. 

1963 

1964 Returns the patch. 

1965 """ 

1966 

1967 self._set_artist_props(p) 

1968 if p.get_clip_path() is None: 

1969 p.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1970 self._update_patch_limits(p) 

1971 self.patches.append(p) 

1972 p._remove_method = self.patches.remove 

1973 return p 

1974 

1975 def _update_patch_limits(self, patch): 

1976 """update the data limits for patch *p*""" 

1977 # hist can add zero height Rectangles, which is useful to keep 

1978 # the bins, counts and patches lined up, but it throws off log 

1979 # scaling. We'll ignore rects with zero height or width in 

1980 # the auto-scaling 

1981 

1982 # cannot check for '==0' since unitized data may not compare to zero 

1983 # issue #2150 - we update the limits if patch has non zero width 

1984 # or height. 

1985 if (isinstance(patch, mpatches.Rectangle) and 

1986 ((not patch.get_width()) and (not patch.get_height()))): 

1987 return 

1988 vertices = patch.get_path().vertices 

1989 if vertices.size > 0: 

1990 xys = patch.get_patch_transform().transform(vertices) 

1991 if patch.get_data_transform() != self.transData: 

1992 patch_to_data = (patch.get_data_transform() - 

1993 self.transData) 

1994 xys = patch_to_data.transform(xys) 

1995 

1996 updatex, updatey = patch.get_transform().\ 

1997 contains_branch_seperately(self.transData) 

1998 self.update_datalim(xys, updatex=updatex, 

1999 updatey=updatey) 

2000 

2001 def add_table(self, tab): 

2002 """ 

2003 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.table.Table` instance to the 

2004 list of axes tables 

2005 

2006 Parameters 

2007 ---------- 

2008 tab: `matplotlib.table.Table` 

2009 Table instance 

2010 

2011 Returns 

2012 ------- 

2013 `matplotlib.table.Table`: the table. 

2014 """ 

2015 self._set_artist_props(tab) 

2016 self.tables.append(tab) 

2017 tab.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

2018 tab._remove_method = self.tables.remove 

2019 return tab 

2020 

2021 def add_container(self, container): 

2022 """ 

2023 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.container.Container` instance 

2024 to the axes.

2026 Returns the collection. 

2027 """ 

2028 label = container.get_label() 

2029 if not label: 

2030 container.set_label('_container%d' % len(self.containers)) 

2031 self.containers.append(container) 

2032 container._remove_method = self.containers.remove

2043 

2044 def relim(self, visible_only=False): 

2045 """ 

2046 Recompute the data limits based on current artists. If you want to 

2047 exclude invisible artists from the calculation, set 

2048 ``visible_only=True`` 

2049 

2050 At present, :class:`~matplotlib.collections.Collection` 

2051 instances are not supported. 

2052 """ 

2053 # Collections are deliberately not supported (yet); see 

2054 # the TODO note in artists.py. 

2055 self.dataLim.ignore(True) 

2056 self.dataLim.set_points(mtransforms.Bbox.null().get_points()) 

2057 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = True 

2058 

2059 for line in self.lines: 

2060 if not visible_only or line.get_visible(): 

2061 self._update_line_limits(line) 

2062 

2063 for p in self.patches: 

2064 if not visible_only or p.get_visible(): 

2065 self._update_patch_limits(p) 

2066 

2067 for image in self.images: 

2068 if not visible_only or image.get_visible(): 

2069 self._update_image_limits(image) 

2070 

2071 def update_datalim(self, xys, updatex=True, updatey=True): 

2072 """ 

2073 Extend the `~.Axes.dataLim` BBox to include the given points. 

2074 

2075 If no data is set currently, the BBox will ignore its limits and set 

2076 the bound to be the bounds of the xydata (*xys*). Otherwise, it will 

2077 compute the bounds of the union of its current data and the data in 

2078 *xys*. 

2079 

2080 Parameters 

2081 ---------- 

2082 xys : 2D array-like 

2083 The points to include in the data limits BBox. This can be either 

2084 a list of (x, y) tuples or a Nx2 array. 

2085 

2086 updatex, updatey : bool, optional, default *True* 

2087 Whether to update the x/y limits. 

2088 """ 

2089 xys = np.asarray(xys) 

2090 if not len(xys): 

2091 return 

2092 self.dataLim.update_from_data_xy(xys, self.ignore_existing_data_limits, 

2093 updatex=updatex, updatey=updatey) 

2094 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = False 

2095 

2096 def update_datalim_bounds(self, bounds): 

2097 """ 

2098 Extend the `~.Axes.datalim` BBox to include the given 

2099 `~matplotlib.transforms.Bbox`. 

2100 

2101 Parameters 

2102 ---------- 

2103 bounds : `~matplotlib.transforms.Bbox` 

2104 """ 

2105 self.dataLim.set(mtransforms.Bbox.union([self.dataLim, bounds])) 

2106 

2107 def _process_unit_info(self, xdata=None, ydata=None, kwargs=None): 

2108 """Look for unit *kwargs* and update the axis instances as necessary""" 

2109 

2110 def _process_single_axis(data, axis, unit_name, kwargs): 

2111 # Return if there's no axis set 

2112 if axis is None: 

2113 return kwargs 

2114 

2115 if data is not None: 

2116 # We only need to update if there is nothing set yet. 

2117 if not axis.have_units(): 

2118 axis.update_units(data) 

2119 

2120 # Check for units in the kwargs, and if present update axis 

2121 if kwargs is not None: 

2122 units = kwargs.pop(unit_name, axis.units) 

2123 if self.name == 'polar': 

2124 polar_units = {'xunits': 'thetaunits', 'yunits': 'runits'} 

2125 units = kwargs.pop(polar_units[unit_name], units) 

2126 

2127 if units != axis.units: 

2128 axis.set_units(units) 

2129 # If the units being set imply a different converter, 

2130 # we need to update. 

2131 if data is not None: 

2132 axis.update_units(data) 

2133 return kwargs 

2134 

2135 kwargs = _process_single_axis(xdata, self.xaxis, 'xunits', kwargs) 

2136 kwargs = _process_single_axis(ydata, self.yaxis, 'yunits', kwargs) 

2137 return kwargs

2196 def use_sticky_edges(self):

2204 example, which would otherwise force a view limit to coincide 

2205 with its data limit. 

2206 

2207 The changing this property does not change the plot until 

2208 `autoscale` or `autoscale_view` is called. 

2209 """

2216 

2217 def set_xmargin(self, m): 

2218 """ 

2219 Set padding of X data limits prior to autoscaling. 

2220 

2221 *m* times the data interval will be added to each 

2222 end of that interval before it is used in autoscaling. 

2223 For example, if your data is in the range [0, 2], a factor of 

2224 ``m = 0.1`` will result in a range [-0.2, 2.2]. 

2225 

2226 Negative values -0.5 < m < 0 will result in clipping of the data range. 

2227 I.e. for a data range [0, 2], a factor of ``m = -0.1`` will result in 

2228 a range [0.2, 1.8]. 

2229 

2230 Parameters 

2231 ---------- 

2232 m : float greater than -0.5 

2233 """ 

2234 if m <= -0.5: 

2235 raise ValueError("margin must be greater than -0.5") 

2236 self._xmargin = m 

2237 self.stale = True 

2238 

2239 def set_ymargin(self, m): 

2240 """ 

2241 Set padding of Y data limits prior to autoscaling. 

2242 

2243 *m* times the data interval will be added to each 

2244 end of that interval before it is used in autoscaling. 

2245 For example, if your data is in the range [0, 2], a factor of 

2246 ``m = 0.1`` will result in a range [-0.2, 2.2]. 

2247 

2248 Negative values -0.5 < m < 0 will result in clipping of the data range. 

2249 I.e. for a data range [0, 2], a factor of ``m = -0.1`` will result in 

2250 a range [0.2, 1.8]. 

2251 

2252 Parameters 

2253 ---------- 

2254 m : float greater than -0.5 

2255 """ 

2256 if m <= -0.5: 

2257 raise ValueError("margin must be greater than -0.5") 

2258 self._ymargin = m 

2259 self.stale = True 

2260 

2261 def margins(self, *margins, x=None, y=None, tight=True): 

2262 """ 

2263 Set or retrieve autoscaling margins. 

2264 

2265 The padding added to each limit of the axes is the *margin* 

2266 times the data interval. All input parameters must be floats 

2267 within the range [0, 1]. Passing both positional and keyword 

2268 arguments is invalid and will raise a TypeError. If no 

2269 arguments (positional or otherwise) are provided, the current 

2270 margins will remain in place and simply be returned. 

2271 

2272 Specifying any margin changes only the autoscaling; for example, 

2273 if *xmargin* is not None, then *xmargin* times the X data 

2274 interval will be added to each end of that interval before 

2275 it is used in autoscaling. 

2276 

2277 Parameters 

2278 ---------- 

2279 args : float, optional 

2280 If a single positional argument is provided, it specifies 

2281 both margins of the x-axis and y-axis limits. If two 

2282 positional arguments are provided, they will be interpreted 

2283 as *xmargin*, *ymargin*. If setting the margin on a single 

2284 axis is desired, use the keyword arguments described below. 

2285 

2286 x, y : float, optional 

2287 Specific margin values for the x-axis and y-axis, 

2288 respectively. These cannot be used with positional 

2289 arguments, but can be used individually to alter on e.g., 

2290 only the y-axis. 

2291 

2292 tight : bool, default is True 

2293 The *tight* parameter is passed to :meth:`autoscale_view`, 

2294 which is executed after a margin is changed; the default 

2295 here is *True*, on the assumption that when margins are 

2296 specified, no additional padding to match tick marks is 

2297 usually desired. Set *tight* to *None* will preserve 

2298 the previous setting. 

2299 

2300 

2301 Returns 

2302 ------- 

2303 xmargin, ymargin : float 

2304 

2305 Notes 

2306 ----- 

2307 If a previously used Axes method such as :meth:`pcolor` has set 

2308 :attr:`use_sticky_edges` to `True`, only the limits not set by 

2309 the "sticky artists" will be modified. To force all of the 

2310 margins to be set, set :attr:`use_sticky_edges` to `False` 

2311 before calling :meth:`margins`. 

2312 

2313 """ 

2314 

2315 if margins and x is not None and y is not None: 

2316 raise TypeError('Cannot pass both positional and keyword ' 

2317 'arguments for x and/or y.') 

2318 elif len(margins) == 1: 

2319 x = y = margins[0] 

2320 elif len(margins) == 2: 

2321 x, y = margins 

2322 elif margins: 

2323 raise TypeError('Must pass a single positional argument for all ' 

2324 'margins, or one for each margin (x, y).') 

2325 

2326 if x is None and y is None: 

2327 if tight is not True: 

2328 warnings.warn('ignoring tight=%r in get mode' % (tight,), 

2329 stacklevel=2) 

2330 return self._xmargin, self._ymargin 

2331 

2332 if x is not None: 

2333 self.set_xmargin(x) 

2334 if y is not None: 

2335 self.set_ymargin(y) 

2336 

2337 self.autoscale_view( 

2338 tight=tight, scalex=(x is not None), scaley=(y is not None) 

2339 ) 

2340

2343 Parameters

2345 z : float or None 

2346 zorder below which artists are rasterized. ``None`` means that 

2347 artists do not get rasterized based on zorder.

2349 self._rasterization_zorder = z 

2350 self.stale = True

2352 def get_rasterization_zorder(self): 

2353 """Return the zorder value below which artists will be rasterized.""" 

2354 return self._rasterization_zorder 

2355 

2356 def autoscale(self, enable=True, axis='both', tight=None): 

2357 """ 

2358 Autoscale the axis view to the data (toggle). 

2359 

2360 Convenience method for simple axis view autoscaling. 

2361 It turns autoscaling on or off, and then, 

2362 if autoscaling for either axis is on, it performs 

2363 the autoscaling on the specified axis or axes. 

2364 

2365 Parameters 

2366 ---------- 

2367 enable : bool or None, optional 

2368 True (default) turns autoscaling on, False turns it off. 

2369 None leaves the autoscaling state unchanged. 

2370 

2371 axis : {'both', 'x', 'y'}, optional 

2372 which axis to operate on; default is 'both' 

2373 

2374 tight: bool or None, optional 

2375 If True, set view limits to data limits; 

2376 if False, let the locator and margins expand the view limits; 

2377 if None, use tight scaling if the only artist is an image, 

2378 otherwise treat *tight* as False. 

2379 The *tight* setting is retained for future autoscaling 

2380 until it is explicitly changed. 

2381 

2382 """ 

2383 if enable is None: 

2384 scalex = True 

2385 scaley = True 

2386 else: 

2387 scalex = False 

2388 scaley = False 

2389 if axis in ['x', 'both']: 

2390 self._autoscaleXon = bool(enable) 

2391 scalex = self._autoscaleXon 

2392 if axis in ['y', 'both']: 

2393 self._autoscaleYon = bool(enable) 

2394 scaley = self._autoscaleYon 

2395 if tight and scalex: 

2396 self._xmargin = 0 

2397 if tight and scaley: 

2398 self._ymargin = 0 

2399 self.autoscale_view(tight=tight, scalex=scalex, scaley=scaley) 

2400 

2401 def autoscale_view(self, tight=None, scalex=True, scaley=True): 

2402 """ 

2403 Autoscale the view limits using the data limits. 

2404 

2405 You can selectively autoscale only a single axis, e.g., the xaxis by 

2406 setting *scaley* to *False*. The autoscaling preserves any 

2407 axis direction reversal that has already been done. 

2408 

2409 If *tight* is *False*, the axis major locator will be used 

2410 to expand the view limits if rcParams['axes.autolimit_mode'] 

2411 is 'round_numbers'. Note that any margins that are in effect 

2412 will be applied first, regardless of whether *tight* is 

2413 *True* or *False*. Specifying *tight* as *True* or *False* 

2414 saves the setting as a private attribute of the Axes; specifying 

2415 it as *None* (the default) applies the previously saved value. 

2416 

2417 The data limits are not updated automatically when artist data are 

2418 changed after the artist has been added to an Axes instance. In that 

2419 case, use :meth:`matplotlib.axes.Axes.relim` prior to calling 

2420 autoscale_view. 

2421 """ 

2422 if tight is not None: 

2423 self._tight = bool(tight) 

2424 

2425 if self.use_sticky_edges and (self._xmargin or self._ymargin): 

2426 stickies = [artist.sticky_edges for artist in self.get_children()] 

2427 x_stickies = sum([sticky.x for sticky in stickies], []) 

2428 y_stickies = sum([sticky.y for sticky in stickies], []) 

2429 if self.get_xscale().lower() == 'log': 

2430 x_stickies = [xs for xs in x_stickies if xs > 0] 

2431 if self.get_yscale().lower() == 'log': 

2432 y_stickies = [ys for ys in y_stickies if ys > 0] 

2433 else: # Small optimization. 

2434 x_stickies, y_stickies = [], [] 

2435 

2436 def handle_single_axis(scale, autoscaleon, shared_axes, interval, 

2437 minpos, axis, margin, stickies, set_bound): 

2438 

2439 if not (scale and autoscaleon): 

2440 return # nothing to do... 

2441 

2442 shared = shared_axes.get_siblings(self) 

2443 dl = [ax.dataLim for ax in shared] 

2444 # ignore non-finite data limits if good limits exist 

2445 finite_dl = [d for d in dl if np.isfinite(d).all()] 

2446 if len(finite_dl): 

2447 # if finite limits exist for atleast one axis (and the 

2448 # other is infinite), restore the finite limits 

2449 x_finite = [d for d in dl 

2450 if (np.isfinite(d.intervalx).all() and 

2451 (d not in finite_dl))] 

2452 y_finite = [d for d in dl 

2453 if (np.isfinite(d.intervaly).all() and 

2454 (d not in finite_dl))] 

2455 

2456 dl = finite_dl 

2457 dl.extend(x_finite) 

2458 dl.extend(y_finite) 

2459 

2460 bb = mtransforms.BboxBase.union(dl) 

2461 x0, x1 = getattr(bb, interval) 

2462 locator = axis.get_major_locator() 

2463 try: 

2464 # e.g., DateLocator has its own nonsingular() 

2465 x0, x1 = locator.nonsingular(x0, x1) 

2466 except AttributeError: 

2467 # Default nonsingular for, e.g., MaxNLocator 

2468 x0, x1 = mtransforms.nonsingular( 

2469 x0, x1, increasing=False, expander=0.05) 

2470 

2471 # Add the margin in figure space and then transform back, to handle 

2472 # non-linear scales. 

2473 minpos = getattr(bb, minpos) 

2474 transform = axis.get_transform() 

2475 inverse_trans = transform.inverted() 

2476 # We cannot use exact equality due to floating point issues e.g. 

2477 # with streamplot. 

2478 do_lower_margin = not np.any(np.isclose(x0, stickies)) 

2479 do_upper_margin = not np.any(np.isclose(x1, stickies)) 

2480 x0, x1 = axis._scale.limit_range_for_scale(x0, x1, minpos) 

2481 x0t, x1t = transform.transform([x0, x1]) 

2482 

2483 if (np.isfinite(x1t) and np.isfinite(x0t)): 

2484 delta = (x1t - x0t) * margin 

2485 else: 

2486 # If at least one bound isn't finite, set margin to zero 

2487 delta = 0 

2488 

2489 if do_lower_margin: 

2490 x0t -= delta 

2491 if do_upper_margin: 

2492 x1t += delta 

2493 x0, x1 = inverse_trans.transform([x0t, x1t]) 

2494 

2495 if not self._tight: 

2496 x0, x1 = locator.view_limits(x0, x1) 

2497 set_bound(x0, x1) 

2498 # End of definition of internal function 'handle_single_axis'. 

2499 

2500 handle_single_axis( 

2501 scalex, self._autoscaleXon, self._shared_x_axes, 'intervalx', 

2502 'minposx', self.xaxis, self._xmargin, x_stickies, self.set_xbound) 

2503 handle_single_axis( 

2504 scaley, self._autoscaleYon, self._shared_y_axes, 'intervaly', 

2505 'minposy', self.yaxis, self._ymargin, y_stickies, self.set_ybound) 

2506 

2507 def _get_axis_list(self): 

2508 return (self.xaxis, self.yaxis) 

2509 

2510 def _update_title_position(self, renderer): 

2511 """ 

2512 Update the title position based on the bounding box enclosing 

2513 all the ticklabels and x-axis spine and xlabel... 

2514 """ 

2515 _log.debug('update_title_pos') 

2516 

2517 if self._autotitlepos is not None and not self._autotitlepos: 

2518 _log.debug('title position was updated manually, not adjusting') 

2519 return 

2520 

2521 titles = (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title) 

2522 

2523 if self._autotitlepos is None: 

2524 for title in titles: 

2525 x, y = title.get_position() 

2526 if not np.isclose(y, 1.0): 

2527 self._autotitlepos = False 

2528 _log.debug('not adjusting title pos because title was' 

2529 ' already placed manually: %f', y) 

2530 return 

2531 self._autotitlepos = True 

2532 

2533 for title in titles: 

2534 x, y0 = title.get_position() 

2535 y = 1.0 

2536 # need to check all our twins too... 

2537 axs = self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self) 

2538 

2539 for ax in axs: 

2540 try: 

2541 if (ax.xaxis.get_label_position() == 'top' 

2542 or ax.xaxis.get_ticks_position() == 'top'): 

2543 bb = ax.xaxis.get_tightbbox(renderer) 

2544 top = bb.ymax 

2545 # we don't need to pad because the padding is already 

2546 # in __init__: titleOffsetTrans 

2547 yn = self.transAxes.inverted().transform((0., top))[1] 

2548 y = max(y, yn) 

2549 except AttributeError: 

2550 pass 

2551 

2552 title.set_position((x, y)) 

2553 

2554 # Drawing 

2555 

2556 @allow_rasterization 

2557 def draw(self, renderer=None, inframe=False): 

2558 """Draw everything (plot lines, axes, labels)""" 

2559 if renderer is None: 

2560 renderer = self._cachedRenderer 

2561 

2562 if renderer is None: 

2563 raise RuntimeError('No renderer defined') 

2564 if not self.get_visible(): 

2565 return 

2566 renderer.open_group('axes') 

2567 

2568 # prevent triggering call backs during the draw process 

2569 self._stale = True 

2570 locator = self.get_axes_locator() 

2571 if locator: 

2572 pos = locator(self, renderer) 

2573 self.apply_aspect(pos) 

2574 else: 

2575 self.apply_aspect() 

2576 

2577 artists = self.get_children() 

2578 artists.remove(self.patch) 

2579 

2580 # the frame draws the edges around the axes patch -- we 

2581 # decouple these so the patch can be in the background and the 

2582 # frame in the foreground. Do this before drawing the axis 

2583 # objects so that the spine has the opportunity to update them. 

2584 if not (self.axison and self._frameon): 

2585 for spine in self.spines.values(): 

2586 artists.remove(spine) 

2587 

2588 self._update_title_position(renderer) 

2589 

2590 if not self.axison or inframe: 

2591 for _axis in self._get_axis_list(): 

2592 artists.remove(_axis) 

2593 

2594 if inframe: 

2595 artists.remove(self.title) 

2596 artists.remove(self._left_title) 

2597 artists.remove(self._right_title) 

2598 

2599 if not self.figure.canvas.is_saving(): 

2600 artists = [a for a in artists 

2601 if not a.get_animated() or a in self.images] 

2602 artists = sorted(artists, key=attrgetter('zorder')) 

2603 

2604 # rasterize artists with negative zorder 

2605 # if the minimum zorder is negative, start rasterization 

2606 rasterization_zorder = self._rasterization_zorder 

2607 

2608 if (rasterization_zorder is not None and 

2609 artists and artists[0].zorder < rasterization_zorder): 

2610 renderer.start_rasterizing() 

2611 artists_rasterized = [a for a in artists 

2612 if a.zorder < rasterization_zorder] 

2613 artists = [a for a in artists 

2614 if a.zorder >= rasterization_zorder] 

2615 else: 

2616 artists_rasterized = [] 

2617 

2618 # the patch draws the background rectangle -- the frame below 

2619 # will draw the edges 

2620 if self.axison and self._frameon: 

2621 self.patch.draw(renderer) 

2622 

2623 if artists_rasterized: 

2624 for a in artists_rasterized: 

2625 a.draw(renderer) 

2626 renderer.stop_rasterizing() 

2627 

2628 mimage._draw_list_compositing_images(renderer, self, artists) 

2629 

2630 renderer.close_group('axes') 

2631 self._cachedRenderer = renderer 

2632 self.stale = False 

2633 

2634 def draw_artist(self, a): 

2635 """ 

2636 This method can only be used after an initial draw which 

2637 caches the renderer. It is used to efficiently update Axes 

2638 data (axis ticks, labels, etc are not updated) 

2639 """ 

2640 if self._cachedRenderer is None: 

2641 raise AttributeError("draw_artist can only be used after an " 

2642 "initial draw which caches the renderer") 

2643 a.draw(self._cachedRenderer) 

2644 

2645 def redraw_in_frame(self): 

2646 """ 

2647 This method can only be used after an initial draw which 

2648 caches the renderer. It is used to efficiently update Axes 

2649 data (axis ticks, labels, etc are not updated) 

2650 """ 

2651 if self._cachedRenderer is None: 

2652 raise AttributeError("redraw_in_frame can only be used after an " 

2653 "initial draw which caches the renderer") 

2654 self.draw(self._cachedRenderer, inframe=True)

2676 def get_axisbelow(self): 

2677 """ 

2678 Get whether axis ticks and gridlines are above or below most artists. 

2679 

2680 Returns 

2681 ------- 

2682 axisbelow : bool or 'line' 

2683 

2684 See Also 

2685 -------- 

2686 set_axisbelow 

2687 """ 

2688 return self._axisbelow 

2689 

2690 def set_axisbelow(self, b): 

2691 """ 

2692 Set whether axis ticks and gridlines are above or below most artists. 

2693 

2694 This controls the zorder of the ticks and gridlines. For more 

2695 information on the zorder see :doc:`/gallery/misc/zorder_demo`. 

2696 

2697 Parameters 

2698 ---------- 

2699 b : bool or 'line' 

2700 Possible values: 

2701 

2702 - *True* (zorder = 0.5): Ticks and gridlines are below all Artists. 

2703 - 'line' (zorder = 1.5): Ticks and gridlines are above patches ( 

2704 e.g. rectangles) but still below lines / markers. 

2705 - *False* (zorder = 2.5): Ticks and gridlines are above patches 

2706 and lines / markers. 

2707 

2708 See Also 

2709 -------- 

2710 get_axisbelow 

2711 """ 

2712 self._axisbelow = axisbelow = validate_axisbelow(b) 

2713 if axisbelow is True: 

2714 zorder = 0.5 

2715 elif axisbelow is False: 

2716 zorder = 2.5 

2717 elif axisbelow == "line": 

2718 zorder = 1.5 

2719 else: 

2720 raise ValueError("Unexpected axisbelow value") 

2721 for axis in self._get_axis_list(): 

2722 axis.set_zorder(zorder) 

2723 self.stale = True

2725 @docstring.dedent_interpd 

2726 def grid(self, b=None, which='major', axis='both', **kwargs): 

2727 """ 

2728 Configure the grid lines. 

2729 

2730 Parameters 

2731 ---------- 

2732 b : bool or None 

2733 Whether to show the grid lines. If any *kwargs* are supplied, 

2734 it is assumed you want the grid on and *b* will be set to True. 

2735 

2736 If *b* is *None* and there are no *kwargs*, this toggles the 

2737 visibility of the lines. 

2738 

2739 which : {'major', 'minor', 'both'} 

2740 The grid lines to apply the changes on. 

2741 

2742 axis : {'both', 'x', 'y'} 

2743 The axis to apply the changes on. 

2744 

2745 **kwargs : `.Line2D` properties 

2746 Define the line properties of the grid, e.g.:: 

2747 

2748 grid(color='r', linestyle='-', linewidth=2) 

2749 

2750 Valid *kwargs* are 

2751 

2752 %(Line2D)s 

2753 

2754 Notes 

2755 ----- 

2756 The grid will be drawn according to the axes' zorder and not its own. 

2757 """ 

2758 if len(kwargs): 

2759 b = True 

2760 elif b is not None: 

2761 b = _string_to_bool(b) 

2762 

2763 if axis == 'x' or axis == 'both': 

2764 self.xaxis.grid(b, which=which, **kwargs) 

2765 if axis == 'y' or axis == 'both': 

2766 self.yaxis.grid(b, which=which, **kwargs)
