2768 def ticklabel_format(self, *, axis='both', style='', scilimits=None, 

2769 useOffset=None, useLocale=None, useMathText=None): 

2770 r""" 

2771 Change the `~matplotlib.ticker.ScalarFormatter` used by 

2772 default for linear axes. 

2773 

2774 Optional keyword arguments: 

2775 

2776 ============== ========================================= 

2777 Keyword Description 

2778 ============== ========================================= 

2779 *axis* [ 'x' | 'y' | 'both' ] 

2780 *style* [ 'sci' (or 'scientific') | 'plain' ] 

2781 plain turns off scientific notation 

2782 *scilimits* (m, n), pair of integers; if *style* 

2783 is 'sci', scientific notation will 

2784 be used for numbers outside the range 

2785 10\ :sup:`m` to 10\ :sup:`n`. 

2786 Use (0,0) to include all numbers. 

2787 Use (m,m) where m <> 0 to fix the order 

2788 of magnitude to 10\ :sup:`m`. 

2789 *useOffset* [ bool | offset ]; if True, 

2790 the offset will be calculated as needed; 

2791 if False, no offset will be used; if a 

2792 numeric offset is specified, it will be 

2793 used. 

2794 *useLocale* If True, format the number according to 

2795 the current locale. This affects things 

2796 such as the character used for the 

2797 decimal separator. If False, use 

2798 C-style (English) formatting. The 

2799 default setting is controlled by the 

2800 axes.formatter.use_locale rcparam. 

2801 *useMathText* If True, render the offset and scientific 

2802 notation in mathtext 

2803 ============== ========================================= 

2804 

2805 Only the major ticks are affected. 

2806 If the method is called when the 

2807 :class:`~matplotlib.ticker.ScalarFormatter` is not the 

2808 :class:`~matplotlib.ticker.Formatter` being used, an 

2809 :exc:`AttributeError` will be raised. 

2810 

2811 """ 

2812 style = style.lower() 

2813 axis = axis.lower() 

2814 if scilimits is not None: 

2815 try: 

2816 m, n = scilimits 

2817 m + n + 1 # check that both are numbers 

2818 except (ValueError, TypeError): 

2819 raise ValueError("scilimits must be a sequence of 2 integers") 

2820 if style[:3] == 'sci': 

2821 sb = True 

2822 elif style == 'plain': 

2823 sb = False 

2824 elif style == '': 

2825 sb = None 

2826 else: 

2827 raise ValueError("%s is not a valid style value") 

2828 try: 

2829 if sb is not None: 

2830 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2831 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_scientific(sb) 

2832 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2833 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_scientific(sb) 

2834 if scilimits is not None: 

2835 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2836 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_powerlimits(scilimits) 

2837 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2838 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_powerlimits(scilimits) 

2839 if useOffset is not None: 

2840 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2841 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_useOffset(useOffset) 

2842 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2843 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_useOffset(useOffset) 

2844 if useLocale is not None: 

2845 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2846 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_useLocale(useLocale) 

2847 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2848 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_useLocale(useLocale) 

2849 if useMathText is not None: 

2850 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2851 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_useMathText(useMathText) 

2852 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2853 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_useMathText(useMathText) 

2854 except AttributeError: 

2855 raise AttributeError( 

2856 "This method only works with the ScalarFormatter.") 

2857 

2858 def locator_params(self, axis='both', tight=None, **kwargs): 

2859 """ 

2860 Control behavior of tick locators. 

2861 

2862 Parameters 

2863 ---------- 

2864 axis : {'both', 'x', 'y'}, optional 

2865 The axis on which to operate. 

2866 

2867 tight : bool or None, optional 

2868 Parameter passed to :meth:`autoscale_view`. 

2869 Default is None, for no change. 

2870 

2871 Other Parameters 

2872 ---------------- 

2873 **kw : 

2874 Remaining keyword arguments are passed to directly to the 

2875 :meth:`~matplotlib.ticker.MaxNLocator.set_params` method. 

2876 

2877 Typically one might want to reduce the maximum number 

2878 of ticks and use tight bounds when plotting small 

2879 subplots, for example:: 

2880 

2881 ax.locator_params(tight=True, nbins=4) 

2882 

2883 Because the locator is involved in autoscaling, 

2884 :meth:`autoscale_view` is called automatically after 

2885 the parameters are changed. 

2886 

2887 This presently works only for the 

2888 :class:`~matplotlib.ticker.MaxNLocator` used 

2889 by default on linear axes, but it may be generalized. 

2890 """ 

2891 _x = axis in ['x', 'both'] 

2892 _y = axis in ['y', 'both'] 

2893 if _x: 

2894 self.xaxis.get_major_locator().set_params(**kwargs) 

2895 if _y: 

2896 self.yaxis.get_major_locator().set_params(**kwargs) 

2897 self.autoscale_view(tight=tight, scalex=_x, scaley=_y)

2899 def tick_params(self, axis='both', **kwargs): 

2900 """Change the appearance of ticks, tick labels, and gridlines. 

2901 

2902 Parameters 

2903 ---------- 

2904 axis : {'x', 'y', 'both'}, optional 

2905 Which axis to apply the parameters to. 

2906 

2907 Other Parameters 

2908 ---------------- 

2909 

2910 axis : {'x', 'y', 'both'} 

2911 Axis on which to operate; default is 'both'. 

2912 

2913 reset : bool 

2914 If *True*, set all parameters to defaults 

2915 before processing other keyword arguments. Default is 

2916 *False*. 

2917 

2918 which : {'major', 'minor', 'both'} 

2919 Default is 'major'; apply arguments to *which* ticks. 

2920 

2921 direction : {'in', 'out', 'inout'} 

2922 Puts ticks inside the axes, outside the axes, or both. 

2923 

2924 length : float 

2925 Tick length in points. 

2926 

2927 width : float 

2928 Tick width in points. 

2929 

2930 color : color 

2931 Tick color; accepts any mpl color spec. 

2932 

2933 pad : float 

2934 Distance in points between tick and label. 

2935 

2936 labelsize : float or str 

2937 Tick label font size in points or as a string (e.g., 'large'). 

2938 

2939 labelcolor : color 

2940 Tick label color; mpl color spec. 

2941 

2942 colors : color 

2943 Changes the tick color and the label color to the same value: 

2944 mpl color spec. 

2945 

2946 zorder : float 

2947 Tick and label zorder. 

2948 

2949 bottom, top, left, right : bool 

2950 Whether to draw the respective ticks. 

2951 

2952 labelbottom, labeltop, labelleft, labelright : bool 

2953 Whether to draw the respective tick labels. 

2954 

2955 labelrotation : float 

2956 Tick label rotation 

2957 

2958 grid_color : color 

2959 Changes the gridline color to the given mpl color spec. 

2960 

2961 grid_alpha : float 

2962 Transparency of gridlines: 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque). 

2963 

2964 grid_linewidth : float 

2965 Width of gridlines in points. 

2966 

2967 grid_linestyle : string 

2968 Any valid :class:`~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` line style spec. 

2969 

2970 Examples 

2971 -------- 

2972 

2973 Usage :: 

2974 

2975 ax.tick_params(direction='out', length=6, width=2, colors='r', 

2976 grid_color='r', grid_alpha=0.5) 

2977 

2978 This will make all major ticks be red, pointing out of the box, 

2979 and with dimensions 6 points by 2 points. Tick labels will 

2980 also be red. Gridlines will be red and translucent. 

2981 

2982 """ 

2983 if axis in ['x', 'both']: 

2984 xkw = dict(kwargs) 

2985 xkw.pop('left', None) 

2986 xkw.pop('right', None) 

2987 xkw.pop('labelleft', None) 

2988 xkw.pop('labelright', None) 

2989 self.xaxis.set_tick_params(**xkw) 

2990 if axis in ['y', 'both']: 

2991 ykw = dict(kwargs) 

2992 ykw.pop('top', None) 

2993 ykw.pop('bottom', None) 

2994 ykw.pop('labeltop', None) 

2995 ykw.pop('labelbottom', None) 

2996 self.yaxis.set_tick_params(**ykw)

3030 def xaxis_inverted(self): 

3031 """ 

3032 Return whether the x-axis is inverted. 

3033 

3034 The axis is inverted if the left value is larger than the right value. 

3035 

3036 See Also 

3037 -------- 

3038 invert_xaxis 

3039 get_xlim, set_xlim 

3040 get_xbound, set_xbound 

3041 """ 

3042 left, right = self.get_xlim() 

3043 return right < left 

3044 

3045 def get_xbound(self): 

3046 """ 

3047 Return the lower and upper x-axis bounds, in increasing order. 

3048 

3049 See Also 

3050 -------- 

3051 set_xbound 

3052 get_xlim, set_xlim 

3053 invert_xaxis, xaxis_inverted 

3054 """ 

3055 left, right = self.get_xlim() 

3056 if left < right: 

3057 return left, right 

3058 else: 

3059 return right, left 

3060 

3061 def set_xbound(self, lower=None, upper=None): 

3062 """ 

3063 Set the lower and upper numerical bounds of the x-axis. 

3064 

3065 This method will honor axes inversion regardless of parameter order. 

3066 It will not change the autoscaling setting (``Axes._autoscaleXon``). 

3067 

3068 Parameters 

3069 ---------- 

3070 lower, upper : float or None 

3071 The lower and upper bounds. If *None*, the respective axis bound 

3072 is not modified. 

3073 

3074 See Also 

3075 -------- 

3076 get_xbound 

3077 get_xlim, set_xlim 

3078 invert_xaxis, xaxis_inverted 

3079 """ 

3080 if upper is None and iterable(lower): 

3081 lower, upper = lower 

3082 

3083 old_lower, old_upper = self.get_xbound() 

3084 

3085 if lower is None: 

3086 lower = old_lower 

3087 if upper is None: 

3088 upper = old_upper 

3089 

3090 if self.xaxis_inverted(): 

3091 if lower < upper: 

3092 self.set_xlim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3093 else: 

3094 self.set_xlim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3095 else: 

3096 if lower < upper: 

3097 self.set_xlim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3098 else: 

3099 self.set_xlim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3100 

3101 def get_xlim(self): 

3102 """ 

3103 Return the x-axis view limits. 

3104 

3105 Returns 

3106 ------- 

3107 left, right : (float, float) 

3108 The current x-axis limits in data coordinates. 

3109 

3110 See Also 

3111 -------- 

3112 set_xlim 

3113 set_xbound, get_xbound 

3114 invert_xaxis, xaxis_inverted 

3115 

3116 Notes 

3117 ----- 

3118 The x-axis may be inverted, in which case the *left* value will 

3119 be greater than the *right* value. 

3120 

3121 """ 

3122 return tuple(self.viewLim.intervalx) 

3123 

3124 def _validate_converted_limits(self, limit, convert): 

3125 """ 

3126 Raise ValueError if converted limits are non-finite. 

3127 

3128 Note that this function also accepts None as a limit argument. 

3129 

3130 Returns 

3131 ------- 

3132 The limit value after call to convert(), or None if limit is None. 

3133 

3134 """ 

3135 if limit is not None: 

3136 converted_limit = convert(limit) 

3137 if (isinstance(converted_limit, Real) 

3138 and not np.isfinite(converted_limit)): 

3139 raise ValueError("Axis limits cannot be NaN or Inf") 

3140 return converted_limit 

3141 

3142 def set_xlim(self, left=None, right=None, emit=True, auto=False, 

3143 *, xmin=None, xmax=None): 

3144 """ 

3145 Set the x-axis view limits. 

3146 

3147 .. ACCEPTS: (left: float, right: float) 

3148 

3149 Parameters 

3150 ---------- 

3151 left : scalar, optional 

3152 The left xlim in data coordinates. Passing *None* leaves the 

3153 limit unchanged. 

3154 

3155 The left and right xlims may be passed as the tuple 

3156 (`left`, `right`) as the first positional argument (or as 

3157 the `left` keyword argument). 

3158 

3159 right : scalar, optional 

3160 The right xlim in data coordinates. Passing *None* leaves the 

3161 limit unchanged. 

3162 

3163 emit : bool, optional 

3164 Whether to notify observers of limit change (default: True). 

3165 

3166 auto : bool or None, optional 

3167 Whether to turn on autoscaling of the x-axis. True turns on, 

3168 False turns off (default action), None leaves unchanged. 

3169 

3170 xmin, xmax : scalar, optional 

3171 These arguments are deprecated and will be removed in a future 

3172 version. They are equivalent to left and right respectively, 

3173 and it is an error to pass both *xmin* and *left* or 

3174 *xmax* and *right*. 

3175 

3176 Returns 

3177 ------- 

3178 left, right : (float, float) 

3179 The new x-axis limits in data coordinates. 

3180 

3181 See Also 

3182 -------- 

3183 get_xlim 

3184 set_xbound, get_xbound 

3185 invert_xaxis, xaxis_inverted 

3186 

3187 Notes 

3188 ----- 

3189 The *left* value may be greater than the *right* value, in which 

3190 case the x-axis values will decrease from left to right. 

3191 

3192 Examples 

3193 -------- 

3194 >>> set_xlim(left, right) 

3195 >>> set_xlim((left, right)) 

3196 >>> left, right = set_xlim(left, right) 

3197 

3198 One limit may be left unchanged. 

3199 

3200 >>> set_xlim(right=right_lim) 

3201 

3202 Limits may be passed in reverse order to flip the direction of 

3203 the x-axis. For example, suppose ``x`` represents the number of 

3204 years before present. The x-axis limits might be set like the 

3205 following so 5000 years ago is on the left of the plot and the 

3206 present is on the right. 

3207 

3208 >>> set_xlim(5000, 0) 

3209 

3210 """ 

3211 if right is None and iterable(left): 

3212 left, right = left 

3213 if xmin is not None: 

3214 cbook.warn_deprecated('3.0', name='`xmin`', 

3215 alternative='`left`', obj_type='argument') 

3216 if left is not None: 

3217 raise TypeError('Cannot pass both `xmin` and `left`') 

3218 left = xmin 

3219 if xmax is not None: 

3220 cbook.warn_deprecated('3.0', name='`xmax`', 

3221 alternative='`right`', obj_type='argument') 

3222 if right is not None: 

3223 raise TypeError('Cannot pass both `xmax` and `right`') 

3224 right = xmax 

3225 

3226 self._process_unit_info(xdata=(left, right)) 

3227 left = self._validate_converted_limits(left, self.convert_xunits) 

3228 right = self._validate_converted_limits(right, self.convert_xunits) 

3229 

3230 old_left, old_right = self.get_xlim() 

3231 if left is None: 

3232 left = old_left 

3233 if right is None: 

3234 right = old_right 

3235 

3236 if left == right: 

3237 warnings.warn( 

3238 ('Attempting to set identical left==right results\n' 

3239 'in singular transformations; automatically expanding.\n' 

3240 'left=%s, right=%s') % (left, right), stacklevel=2) 

3241 left, right = mtransforms.nonsingular(left, right, increasing=False) 

3242 

3243 if self.get_xscale() == 'log': 

3244 if left <= 0: 

3245 warnings.warn( 

3246 'Attempted to set non-positive left xlim on a ' 

3247 'log-scaled axis.\n' 

3248 'Invalid limit will be ignored.', stacklevel=2) 

3249 left = old_left 

3250 if right <= 0: 

3251 warnings.warn( 

3252 'Attempted to set non-positive right xlim on a ' 

3253 'log-scaled axis.\n' 

3254 'Invalid limit will be ignored.', stacklevel=2) 

3255 right = old_right 

3256 

3257 left, right = self.xaxis.limit_range_for_scale(left, right) 

3258 

3259 self.viewLim.intervalx = (left, right) 

3260 if auto is not None: 

3261 self._autoscaleXon = bool(auto) 

3262 

3263 if emit: 

3264 self.callbacks.process('xlim_changed', self) 

3265 # Call all of the other x-axes that are shared with this one 

3266 for other in self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self): 

3267 if other is not self: 

3268 other.set_xlim(self.viewLim.intervalx, 

3269 emit=False, auto=auto) 

3270 if (other.figure != self.figure and 

3271 other.figure.canvas is not None): 

3272 other.figure.canvas.draw_idle() 

3273 self.stale = True 

3274 return left, right 

3275

3318 self.autoscale_view(scaley=False)

3426 def invert_yaxis(self): 

3427 """

3436 self.set_ylim(self.get_ylim()[::-1], auto=None) 

3437 

3438 def yaxis_inverted(self): 

3439 """ 

3440 Return whether the y-axis is inverted. 

3441 

3442 The axis is inverted if the bottom value is larger than the top value. 

3443 

3444 See Also 

3445 -------- 

3446 invert_yaxis 

3447 get_ylim, set_ylim 

3448 get_ybound, set_ybound 

3449 """ 

3450 bottom, top = self.get_ylim() 

3451 return top < bottom 

3452 

3453 def get_ybound(self): 

3454 """ 

3455 Return the lower and upper y-axis bounds, in increasing order. 

3456 

3457 See Also 

3458 -------- 

3459 set_ybound 

3460 get_ylim, set_ylim 

3461 invert_yaxis, yaxis_inverted 

3462 """ 

3463 bottom, top = self.get_ylim() 

3464 if bottom < top: 

3465 return bottom, top 

3466 else: 

3467 return top, bottom 

3468 

3469 def set_ybound(self, lower=None, upper=None): 

3470 """ 

3471 Set the lower and upper numerical bounds of the y-axis. 

3472 

3473 This method will honor axes inversion regardless of parameter order. 

3474 It will not change the autoscaling setting (``Axes._autoscaleYon``). 

3475 

3476 Parameters 

3477 ---------- 

3478 lower, upper : float or None 

3479 The lower and upper bounds. If *None*, the respective axis bound 

3480 is not modified. 

3481 

3482 See Also 

3483 -------- 

3484 get_ybound 

3485 get_ylim, set_ylim 

3486 invert_yaxis, yaxis_inverted 

3487 """ 

3488 if upper is None and iterable(lower): 

3489 lower, upper = lower 

3490 

3491 old_lower, old_upper = self.get_ybound() 

3492 

3493 if lower is None: 

3494 lower = old_lower 

3495 if upper is None: 

3496 upper = old_upper 

3497 

3498 if self.yaxis_inverted(): 

3499 if lower < upper: 

3500 self.set_ylim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3501 else: 

3502 self.set_ylim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3503 else: 

3504 if lower < upper: 

3505 self.set_ylim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3506 else: 

3507 self.set_ylim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3508 

3509 def get_ylim(self): 

3510 """ 

3511 Return the y-axis view limits. 

3512 

3513 Returns 

3514 ------- 

3515 bottom, top : (float, float) 

3516 The current y-axis limits in data coordinates. 

3517 

3518 See Also 

3519 -------- 

3520 set_ylim 

3521 set_ybound, get_ybound 

3522 invert_yaxis, yaxis_inverted 

3523 

3524 Notes 

3525 ----- 

3526 The y-axis may be inverted, in which case the *bottom* value 

3527 will be greater than the *top* value. 

3528 

3529 """ 

3530 return tuple(self.viewLim.intervaly) 

3531 

3532 def set_ylim(self, bottom=None, top=None, emit=True, auto=False, 

3533 *, ymin=None, ymax=None): 

3534 """ 

3535 Set the y-axis view limits. 

3536 

3537 .. ACCEPTS: (bottom: float, top: float) 

3538 

3539 Parameters 

3540 ---------- 

3541 bottom : scalar, optional 

3542 The bottom ylim in data coordinates. Passing *None* leaves the 

3543 limit unchanged. 

3544 

3545 The bottom and top ylims may be passed as the tuple 

3546 (`bottom`, `top`) as the first positional argument (or as 

3547 the `bottom` keyword argument). 

3548 

3549 top : scalar, optional 

3550 The top ylim in data coordinates. Passing *None* leaves the 

3551 limit unchanged. 

3552 

3553 emit : bool, optional 

3554 Whether to notify observers of limit change (default: True). 

3555 

3556 auto : bool or None, optional 

3557 Whether to turn on autoscaling of the y-axis. *True* turns on, 

3558 *False* turns off (default action), *None* leaves unchanged. 

3559 

3560 ymin, ymax : scalar, optional 

3561 These arguments are deprecated and will be removed in a future 

3562 version. They are equivalent to bottom and top respectively, 

3563 and it is an error to pass both *ymin* and *bottom* or 

3564 *ymax* and *top*. 

3565 

3566 Returns 

3567 ------- 

3568 bottom, top : (float, float) 

3569 The new y-axis limits in data coordinates. 

3570 

3571 See Also 

3572 -------- 

3573 get_ylim 

3574 set_ybound, get_ybound 

3575 invert_yaxis, yaxis_inverted 

3576 

3577 Notes 

3578 ----- 

3579 The *bottom* value may be greater than the *top* value, in which 

3580 case the y-axis values will decrease from *bottom* to *top*. 

3581 

3582 Examples 

3583 -------- 

3584 >>> set_ylim(bottom, top) 

3585 >>> set_ylim((bottom, top)) 

3586 >>> bottom, top = set_ylim(bottom, top) 

3587 

3588 One limit may be left unchanged. 

3589 

3590 >>> set_ylim(top=top_lim) 

3591 

3592 Limits may be passed in reverse order to flip the direction of 

3593 the y-axis. For example, suppose ``y`` represents depth of the 

3594 ocean in m. The y-axis limits might be set like the following 

3595 so 5000 m depth is at the bottom of the plot and the surface, 

3596 0 m, is at the top. 

3597 

3598 >>> set_ylim(5000, 0) 

3599 """ 

3600 if top is None and iterable(bottom): 

3601 bottom, top = bottom 

3602 if ymin is not None: 

3603 cbook.warn_deprecated('3.0', name='`ymin`', 

3604 alternative='`bottom`', obj_type='argument') 

3605 if bottom is not None: 

3606 raise TypeError('Cannot pass both `ymin` and `bottom`') 

3607 bottom = ymin 

3608 if ymax is not None: 

3609 cbook.warn_deprecated('3.0', name='`ymax`', 

3610 alternative='`top`', obj_type='argument') 

3611 if top is not None: 

3612 raise TypeError('Cannot pass both `ymax` and `top`') 

3613 top = ymax 

3614 

3615 self._process_unit_info(ydata=(bottom, top)) 

3616 bottom = self._validate_converted_limits(bottom, self.convert_yunits) 

3617 top = self._validate_converted_limits(top, self.convert_yunits) 

3618 

3619 old_bottom, old_top = self.get_ylim() 

3620 

3621 if bottom is None: 

3622 bottom = old_bottom 

3623 if top is None: 

3624 top = old_top 

3625 

3626 if bottom == top: 

3627 warnings.warn( 

3628 ('Attempting to set identical bottom==top results\n' 

3629 'in singular transformations; automatically expanding.\n' 

3630 'bottom=%s, top=%s') % (bottom, top), stacklevel=2) 

3631 

3632 bottom, top = mtransforms.nonsingular(bottom, top, increasing=False) 

3633 

3634 if self.get_yscale() == 'log': 

3635 if bottom <= 0: 

3636 warnings.warn( 

3637 'Attempted to set non-positive bottom ylim on a ' 

3638 'log-scaled axis.\n' 

3639 'Invalid limit will be ignored.', stacklevel=2) 

3640 bottom = old_bottom 

3641 if top <= 0: 

3642 warnings.warn( 

3643 'Attempted to set non-positive top ylim on a ' 

3644 'log-scaled axis.\n' 

3645 'Invalid limit will be ignored.', stacklevel=2) 

3646 top = old_top 

3647 bottom, top = self.yaxis.limit_range_for_scale(bottom, top) 

3648 

3649 self.viewLim.intervaly = (bottom, top) 

3650 if auto is not None: 

3651 self._autoscaleYon = bool(auto) 

3652 

3653 if emit: 

3654 self.callbacks.process('ylim_changed', self) 

3655 # Call all of the other y-axes that are shared with this one 

3656 for other in self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self): 

3657 if other is not self: 

3658 other.set_ylim(self.viewLim.intervaly, 

3659 emit=False, auto=auto) 

3660 if (other.figure != self.figure and 

3661 other.figure.canvas is not None): 

3662 other.figure.canvas.draw_idle() 

3663 self.stale = True 

3664 return bottom, top

3836 def format_xdata(self, x): 

3837 """ 

3838 Return *x* string formatted. This function will use the attribute 

3839 self.fmt_xdata if it is callable, else will fall back on the xaxis 

3840 major formatter 

3841 """ 

3842 try: 

3843 return self.fmt_xdata(x) 

3844 except TypeError: 

3845 func = self.xaxis.get_major_formatter().format_data_short 

3846 val = func(x) 

3847 return val 

3848 

3849 def format_ydata(self, y): 

3850 """ 

3851 Return y string formatted. This function will use the 

3852 :attr:`fmt_ydata` attribute if it is callable, else will fall 

3853 back on the yaxis major formatter 

3854 """ 

3855 try: 

3856 return self.fmt_ydata(y) 

3857 except TypeError: 

3858 func = self.yaxis.get_major_formatter().format_data_short 

3859 val = func(y) 

3860 return val 

3861 

3862 def format_coord(self, x, y): 

3863 """Return a format string formatting the *x*, *y* coord""" 

3864 if x is None: 

3865 xs = '???' 

3866 else: 

3867 xs = self.format_xdata(x) 

3868 if y is None: 

3869 ys = '???' 

3870 else: 

3871 ys = self.format_ydata(y) 

3872 return 'x=%s y=%s' % (xs, ys) 

3873 

3874 def minorticks_on(self): 

3875 """ 

3876 Display minor ticks on the axes. 

3877 

3878 Displaying minor ticks may reduce performance; you may turn them off 

3879 using `minorticks_off()` if drawing speed is a problem. 

3880 """ 

3881 for ax in (self.xaxis, self.yaxis): 

3882 scale = ax.get_scale() 

3883 if scale == 'log': 

3884 s = ax._scale 

3885 ax.set_minor_locator(mticker.LogLocator(s.base, s.subs)) 

3886 elif scale == 'symlog': 

3887 s = ax._scale 

3888 ax.set_minor_locator( 

3889 mticker.SymmetricalLogLocator(s._transform, s.subs)) 

3890 else: 

3891 ax.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator()) 

3892 

3893 def minorticks_off(self): 

3894 """Remove minor ticks from the axes.""" 

3895 self.xaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.NullLocator()) 

3896 self.yaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.NullLocator())

3918 def set_navigate(self, b): 

3919 """ 

3920 Set whether the axes responds to navigation toolbar commands 

3921 

3922 Parameters 

3923 ---------- 

3924 b : bool 

3925 """ 

3926 self._navigate = b

3944 def _get_view(self): 

3945 """ 

3946 Save information required to reproduce the current view. 

3947 

3948 Called before a view is changed, such as during a pan or zoom 

3949 initiated by the user. You may return any information you deem 

3950 necessary to describe the view. 

3951 

3952 .. note:: 

3953 

3954 Intended to be overridden by new projection types, but if not, the 

3955 default implementation saves the view limits. You *must* implement 

3956 :meth:`_set_view` if you implement this method. 

3957 """ 

3958 xmin, xmax = self.get_xlim() 

3959 ymin, ymax = self.get_ylim() 

3960 return (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) 

3961 

3962 def _set_view(self, view): 

3963 """ 

3964 Apply a previously saved view. 

3965 

3966 Called when restoring a view, such as with the navigation buttons. 

3967 

3968 .. note:: 

3969 

3970 Intended to be overridden by new projection types, but if not, the 

3971 default implementation restores the view limits. You *must* 

3972 implement :meth:`_get_view` if you implement this method. 

3973 """ 

3974 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = view 

3975 self.set_xlim((xmin, xmax)) 

3976 self.set_ylim((ymin, ymax)) 

3977 

3978 def _set_view_from_bbox(self, bbox, direction='in', 

3979 mode=None, twinx=False, twiny=False): 

3980 """ 

3981 Update view from a selection bbox. 

3982 

3983 .. note:: 

3984 

3985 Intended to be overridden by new projection types, but if not, the 

3986 default implementation sets the view limits to the bbox directly. 

3987 

3988 Parameters 

3989 ---------- 

3990 

3991 bbox : 4-tuple or 3 tuple 

3992 * If bbox is a 4 tuple, it is the selected bounding box limits, 

3993 in *display* coordinates. 

3994 * If bbox is a 3 tuple, it is an (xp, yp, scl) triple, where 

3995 (xp,yp) is the center of zooming and scl the scale factor to 

3996 zoom by. 

3997 

3998 direction : str 

3999 The direction to apply the bounding box. 

4000 * `'in'` - The bounding box describes the view directly, i.e., 

4001 it zooms in. 

4002 * `'out'` - The bounding box describes the size to make the 

4003 existing view, i.e., it zooms out. 

4004 

4005 mode : str or None 

4006 The selection mode, whether to apply the bounding box in only the 

4007 `'x'` direction, `'y'` direction or both (`None`). 

4008 

4009 twinx : bool 

4010 Whether this axis is twinned in the *x*-direction. 

4011 

4012 twiny : bool 

4013 Whether this axis is twinned in the *y*-direction. 

4014 """ 

4015 Xmin, Xmax = self.get_xlim() 

4016 Ymin, Ymax = self.get_ylim() 

4017 

4018 if len(bbox) == 3: 

4019 # Zooming code 

4020 xp, yp, scl = bbox 

4021 

4022 # Should not happen 

4023 if scl == 0: 

4024 scl = 1. 

4025 

4026 # direction = 'in' 

4027 if scl > 1: 

4028 direction = 'in' 

4029 else: 

4030 direction = 'out' 

4031 scl = 1/scl 

4032 

4033 # get the limits of the axes 

4034 tranD2C = self.transData.transform 

4035 xmin, ymin = tranD2C((Xmin, Ymin)) 

4036 xmax, ymax = tranD2C((Xmax, Ymax)) 

4037 

4038 # set the range 

4039 xwidth = xmax - xmin 

4040 ywidth = ymax - ymin 

4041 xcen = (xmax + xmin)*.5 

4042 ycen = (ymax + ymin)*.5 

4043 xzc = (xp*(scl - 1) + xcen)/scl 

4044 yzc = (yp*(scl - 1) + ycen)/scl 

4045 

4046 bbox = [xzc - xwidth/2./scl, yzc - ywidth/2./scl, 

4047 xzc + xwidth/2./scl, yzc + ywidth/2./scl] 

4048 elif len(bbox) != 4: 

4049 # should be len 3 or 4 but nothing else 

4050 warnings.warn( 

4051 "Warning in _set_view_from_bbox: bounding box is not a tuple " 

4052 "of length 3 or 4. Ignoring the view change.", stacklevel=2) 

4053 return 

4054 

4055 # Just grab bounding box 

4056 lastx, lasty, x, y = bbox 

4057 

4058 # zoom to rect 

4059 inverse = self.transData.inverted() 

4060 lastx, lasty = inverse.transform_point((lastx, lasty)) 

4061 x, y = inverse.transform_point((x, y)) 

4062 

4063 if twinx: 

4064 x0, x1 = Xmin, Xmax 

4065 else: 

4066 if Xmin < Xmax: 

4067 if x < lastx: 

4068 x0, x1 = x, lastx 

4069 else: 

4070 x0, x1 = lastx, x 

4071 if x0 < Xmin: 

4072 x0 = Xmin 

4073 if x1 > Xmax: 

4074 x1 = Xmax 

4075 else: 

4076 if x > lastx: 

4077 x0, x1 = x, lastx 

4078 else: 

4079 x0, x1 = lastx, x 

4080 if x0 > Xmin: 

4081 x0 = Xmin 

4082 if x1 < Xmax: 

4083 x1 = Xmax 

4084 

4085 if twiny: 

4086 y0, y1 = Ymin, Ymax 

4087 else: 

4088 if Ymin < Ymax: 

4089 if y < lasty: 

4090 y0, y1 = y, lasty 

4091 else: 

4092 y0, y1 = lasty, y 

4093 if y0 < Ymin: 

4094 y0 = Ymin 

4095 if y1 > Ymax: 

4096 y1 = Ymax 

4097 else: 

4098 if y > lasty: 

4099 y0, y1 = y, lasty 

4100 else: 

4101 y0, y1 = lasty, y 

4102 if y0 > Ymin: 

4103 y0 = Ymin 

4104 if y1 < Ymax: 

4105 y1 = Ymax 

4106 

4107 if direction == 'in': 

4108 if mode == 'x': 

4109 self.set_xlim((x0, x1)) 

4110 elif mode == 'y': 

4111 self.set_ylim((y0, y1)) 

4112 else: 

4113 self.set_xlim((x0, x1)) 

4114 self.set_ylim((y0, y1)) 

4115 elif direction == 'out': 

4116 if self.get_xscale() == 'log': 

4117 alpha = np.log(Xmax / Xmin) / np.log(x1 / x0) 

4118 rx1 = pow(Xmin / x0, alpha) * Xmin 

4119 rx2 = pow(Xmax / x0, alpha) * Xmin 

4120 else: 

4121 alpha = (Xmax - Xmin) / (x1 - x0) 

4122 rx1 = alpha * (Xmin - x0) + Xmin 

4123 rx2 = alpha * (Xmax - x0) + Xmin 

4124 if self.get_yscale() == 'log': 

4125 alpha = np.log(Ymax / Ymin) / np.log(y1 / y0) 

4126 ry1 = pow(Ymin / y0, alpha) * Ymin 

4127 ry2 = pow(Ymax / y0, alpha) * Ymin 

4128 else: 

4129 alpha = (Ymax - Ymin) / (y1 - y0) 

4130 ry1 = alpha * (Ymin - y0) + Ymin 

4131 ry2 = alpha * (Ymax - y0) + Ymin 

4132 

4133 if mode == 'x': 

4134 self.set_xlim((rx1, rx2)) 

4135 elif mode == 'y': 

4136 self.set_ylim((ry1, ry2)) 

4137 else: 

4138 self.set_xlim((rx1, rx2)) 

4139 self.set_ylim((ry1, ry2))

4141 def start_pan(self, x, y, button): 

4142 """ 

4143 Called when a pan operation has started. 

4144 

4145 *x*, *y* are the mouse coordinates in display coords. 

4146 button is the mouse button number: 

4147 

4148 * 1: LEFT 

4149 * 2: MIDDLE 

4150 * 3: RIGHT 

4151 

4152 .. note:: 

4153 

4154 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

4155 

4156 """ 

4157 self._pan_start = types.SimpleNamespace( 

4158 lim=self.viewLim.frozen(), 

4159 trans=self.transData.frozen(), 

4160 trans_inverse=self.transData.inverted().frozen(), 

4161 bbox=self.bbox.frozen(), 

4162 x=x, 

4163 y=y) 

4164 

4165 def end_pan(self): 

4166 """ 

4167 Called when a pan operation completes (when the mouse button 

4168 is up.) 

4169 

4170 .. note:: 

4171 

4172 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

4173 

4174 """ 

4175 del self._pan_start 

4176 

4177 def drag_pan(self, button, key, x, y): 

4178 """ 

4179 Called when the mouse moves during a pan operation. 

4180 

4181 *button* is the mouse button number: 

4182 

4183 * 1: LEFT 

4184 * 2: MIDDLE 

4185 * 3: RIGHT 

4186 

4187 *key* is a "shift" key 

4188 

4189 *x*, *y* are the mouse coordinates in display coords. 

4190 

4191 .. note:: 

4192 

4193 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

4194 

4195 """ 

4196 def format_deltas(key, dx, dy): 

4197 if key == 'control': 

4198 if abs(dx) > abs(dy): 

4199 dy = dx 

4200 else: 

4201 dx = dy 

4202 elif key == 'x': 

4203 dy = 0 

4204 elif key == 'y': 

4205 dx = 0 

4206 elif key == 'shift': 

4207 if 2 * abs(dx) < abs(dy): 

4208 dx = 0 

4209 elif 2 * abs(dy) < abs(dx): 

4210 dy = 0 

4211 elif abs(dx) > abs(dy): 

4212 dy = dy / abs(dy) * abs(dx) 

4213 else: 

4214 dx = dx / abs(dx) * abs(dy) 

4215 return dx, dy 

4216 

4217 p = self._pan_start 

4218 dx = x - p.x 

4219 dy = y - p.y 

4220 if dx == dy == 0: 

4221 return 

4222 if button == 1: 

4223 dx, dy = format_deltas(key, dx, dy) 

4224 result = p.bbox.translated(-dx, -dy).transformed(p.trans_inverse) 

4225 elif button == 3: 

4226 try: 

4227 dx = -dx / self.bbox.width 

4228 dy = -dy / self.bbox.height 

4229 dx, dy = format_deltas(key, dx, dy) 

4230 if self.get_aspect() != 'auto': 

4231 dx = dy = 0.5 * (dx + dy) 

4232 alpha = np.power(10.0, (dx, dy)) 

4233 start = np.array([p.x, p.y]) 

4234 oldpoints = p.lim.transformed(p.trans) 

4235 newpoints = start + alpha * (oldpoints - start) 

4236 result = (mtransforms.Bbox(newpoints) 

4237 .transformed(p.trans_inverse)) 

4238 except OverflowError: 

4239 warnings.warn('Overflow while panning', stacklevel=2) 

4240 return 

4241 else: 

4242 return 

4243 

4244 valid = np.isfinite(result.transformed(p.trans)) 

4245 points = result.get_points().astype(object) 

4246 # Just ignore invalid limits (typically, underflow in log-scale). 

4247 points[~valid] = None 

4248 self.set_xlim(points[:, 0]) 

4249 self.set_ylim(points[:, 1])

4251 def get_children(self): 

4252 """return a list of child artists""" 

4253 children = [] 

4254 children.extend(self.collections) 

4255 children.extend(self.patches) 

4256 children.extend(self.lines) 

4257 children.extend(self.texts) 

4258 children.extend(self.artists) 

4259 children.extend(self.spines.values()) 

4260 children.append(self.xaxis) 

4261 children.append(self.yaxis) 

4262 children.append(self.title) 

4263 children.append(self._left_title) 

4264 children.append(self._right_title) 

4265 children.extend(self.tables) 

4266 children.extend(self.images) 

4267 children.extend(self.child_axes) 

4268 

4269 if self.legend_ is not None: 

4270 children.append(self.legend_) 

4271 children.append(self.patch) 

4272 

4273 return children

4283 return self.patch.contains(mouseevent)

4306 def get_default_bbox_extra_artists(self): 

4307 """ 

4308 Return a default list of artists that are used for the bounding box 

4309 calculation. 

4310 

4311 Artists are excluded either by not being visible or 

4312 ``artist.set_in_layout(False)``. 

4313 """ 

4314 

4315 artists = self.get_children() 

4316 if not (self.axison and self._frameon): 

4317 # don't do bbox on spines if frame not on. 

4318 for spine in self.spines.values(): 

4319 artists.remove(spine) 

4320 

4321 if not self.axison: 

4322 for _axis in self._get_axis_list(): 

4323 artists.remove(_axis) 

4324 

4325 return [artist for artist in artists 

4326 if (artist.get_visible() and artist.get_in_layout())] 

4327 

4328 def get_tightbbox(self, renderer, call_axes_locator=True, 

4329 bbox_extra_artists=None): 

4330 """ 

4331 Return the tight bounding box of the axes, including axis and their 

4332 decorators (xlabel, title, etc). 

4333 

4334 Artists that have ``artist.set_in_layout(False)`` are not included 

4335 in the bbox. 

4336 

4337 Parameters 

4338 ---------- 

4339 renderer : `.RendererBase` instance 

4340 renderer that will be used to draw the figures (i.e. 

4341 ``fig.canvas.get_renderer()``) 

4342 

4343 bbox_extra_artists : list of `.Artist` or ``None`` 

4344 List of artists to include in the tight bounding box. If 

4345 ``None`` (default), then all artist children of the axes are 

4346 included in the tight bounding box. 

4347 

4348 call_axes_locator : boolean (default ``True``) 

4349 If *call_axes_locator* is ``False``, it does not call the 

4350 ``_axes_locator`` attribute, which is necessary to get the correct 

4351 bounding box. ``call_axes_locator=False`` can be used if the 

4352 caller is only interested in the relative size of the tightbbox 

4353 compared to the axes bbox. 

4354 

4355 Returns 

4356 ------- 

4357 bbox : `.BboxBase` 

4358 bounding box in figure pixel coordinates. 

4359 """ 

4360 

4361 bb = [] 

4362 

4363 if not self.get_visible(): 

4364 return None 

4365 

4366 locator = self.get_axes_locator() 

4367 if locator and call_axes_locator: 

4368 pos = locator(self, renderer) 

4369 self.apply_aspect(pos) 

4370 else: 

4371 self.apply_aspect() 

4372 

4373 bb_xaxis = self.xaxis.get_tightbbox(renderer) 

4374 if bb_xaxis: 

4375 bb.append(bb_xaxis) 

4376 

4377 self._update_title_position(renderer) 

4378 bb.append(self.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4379 

4380 if self.title.get_visible(): 

4381 bb.append(self.title.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4382 if self._left_title.get_visible(): 

4383 bb.append(self._left_title.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4384 if self._right_title.get_visible(): 

4385 bb.append(self._right_title.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4386 

4387 bb_yaxis = self.yaxis.get_tightbbox(renderer) 

4388 if bb_yaxis: 

4389 bb.append(bb_yaxis) 

4390 

4391 bbox_artists = bbox_extra_artists 

4392 if bbox_artists is None: 

4393 bbox_artists = self.get_default_bbox_extra_artists() 

4394 

4395 for a in bbox_artists: 

4396 bbox = a.get_tightbbox(renderer) 

4397 if (bbox is not None and 

4398 (bbox.width != 0 or bbox.height != 0) and 

4399 np.isfinite(bbox.width) and np.isfinite(bbox.height)): 

4400 bb.append(bbox) 

4401 

4402 _bbox = mtransforms.Bbox.union( 

4403 [b for b in bb if b.width != 0 or b.height != 0]) 

4404 

4405 return _bbox

4407 def _make_twin_axes(self, *kl, **kwargs): 

4408 """ 

4409 Make a twinx axes of self. This is used for twinx and twiny. 

4410 """ 

4411 # Typically, SubplotBase._make_twin_axes is called instead of this. 

4412 # There is also an override in axes_grid1/axes_divider.py. 

4413 if 'sharex' in kwargs and 'sharey' in kwargs: 

4414 raise ValueError("Twinned Axes may share only one axis.") 

4415 ax2 = self.figure.add_axes(self.get_position(True), *kl, **kwargs) 

4416 self.set_adjustable('datalim') 

4417 ax2.set_adjustable('datalim') 

4418 self._twinned_axes.join(self, ax2) 

4419 return ax2

4421 def twinx(self): 

4422 """ 

4423 Create a twin Axes sharing the xaxis 

4424 

4425 Create a new Axes instance with an invisible x-axis and an independent 

4426 y-axis positioned opposite to the original one (i.e. at right). The 

4427 x-axis autoscale setting will be inherited from the original Axes. 

4428 To ensure that the tick marks of both y-axes align, see 

4429 `~matplotlib.ticker.LinearLocator` 

4430 

4431 Returns 

4432 ------- 

4433 ax_twin : Axes 

4434 The newly created Axes instance 

4435 

4436 Notes 

4437 ----- 

4438 For those who are 'picking' artists while using twinx, pick 

4439 events are only called for the artists in the top-most axes. 

4440 """ 

4441 ax2 = self._make_twin_axes(sharex=self) 

4442 ax2.yaxis.tick_right() 

4443 ax2.yaxis.set_label_position('right') 

4444 ax2.yaxis.set_offset_position('right') 

4445 ax2.set_autoscalex_on(self.get_autoscalex_on()) 

4446 self.yaxis.tick_left() 

4447 ax2.xaxis.set_visible(False) 

4448 ax2.patch.set_visible(False) 

4449 return ax2 

4450 

4451 def twiny(self): 

4452 """ 

4453 Create a twin Axes sharing the yaxis 

4454 

4455 Create a new Axes instance with an invisible y-axis and an independent 

4456 x-axis positioned opposite to the original one (i.e. at top). The 

4457 y-axis autoscale setting will be inherited from the original Axes. 

4458 To ensure that the tick marks of both x-axes align, see 

4459 `~matplotlib.ticker.LinearLocator` 

4460 

4461 Returns 

4462 ------- 

4463 ax_twin : Axes 

4464 The newly created Axes instance 

4465 

4466 Notes 

4467 ----- 

4468 For those who are 'picking' artists while using twiny, pick 

4469 events are only called for the artists in the top-most axes. 

4470 """ 

4471 

4472 ax2 = self._make_twin_axes(sharey=self) 

4473 ax2.xaxis.tick_top() 

4474 ax2.xaxis.set_label_position('top') 

4475 ax2.set_autoscaley_on(self.get_autoscaley_on()) 

4476 self.xaxis.tick_bottom() 

4477 ax2.yaxis.set_visible(False) 

4478 ax2.patch.set_visible(False) 

4479 return ax2
